characters: HAZARDOUS WASTE ASSOCIATION MEET YOUR REPRESENTATIVE NIGH

dialogues.speaker: A FLASH OF LIGHT
dialogues.text: A radiant shiny something dazzling in EXTREME CLOSEUP. BEGIN TITLES. CAMERA very slowly PULLS   BACK. The sparkling surface turns out to be a lot of   carats. WE SEE the stone, then the ring, then suddenly,   in b.g., something HUGE SWEEPS by. REVEAL a mechanical    claw above the ring, hanging from a crane. The ring    sits in a sea of tiny dolls, joke eyeballs, and other   carnival junk. The claw descends on the ring again and again, sometimes catching it for a moment then tragically dropping it -- accompanied by OOHS and AAHS (O.S.) of hope and disap- pointment. INTERCUT with the HANDS of a young black man working the controls. The EYES of a young black woman watching him work. Another guy's HANDS digging in his pocket for change. QUARTERS going into the slot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This'll never work, Tommy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be positive, Armando. Course it will. The claw inadvertently snags a rabbit's foot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look.   See what a lucky fuck I am?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He don't mean the ring, hon, he means the whole plan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So do I. The claw catches the   ring and closes on it. QUICK CUTS of their FACES as the   crane rises. A very pretty lady. A beefy Latino with a   two-day beard. Their apprehension Tommy's confidence.    Then his exceptional smile. He get the ring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay -- one down, one to go. (returning to the claw)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got quarters, Loretta? END TITLES. THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92              2.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Palm trees. The smell of money. Valets in Foreign Legion khakis greeting arriving luxury cars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A big crowd of GUESTS at a cocktail reception. A lot of lime jackets, cherry trousers, and blue hair. People wear name tags. ON Tommy, in pastel bow tie and full waiter drag, con- firming orders for a group of guests. He speaks in a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a diet ginger ale, an extra- spicy virgin mary no salt, a club soda -- good choice -- a lime rickey, and a bourbon and a planter's punch. Five people, five drinks... it's Kismet! Tommy turns away, looking toward the entrance to the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: glittering on Loretta's finger. LORETTA, stunning in designer clothing and accessories, enters. Her looks attract looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommy, maintaining his vantage point, repeats another order, this time in a heavy CARRIBEAN ACCENT:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a vodka tonic, a Pellegrino, lime and no ice, a gin Gibson straight up with ex-tra onions -- I am also fond of de onions -- and a Chardonnary spritzer...also with extra onions -- no, no, do not worry, that is just a little joke. There will be no onions whatsoever in your spritzer! He LAUGHS HUGELY, rather amused with himself.   The guest aren't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't need to write it down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            3.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Memory?   Do not make me laugh! He LAUGHS HUGELY, turns, takes two steps away and makes absolutely no effort to get their drinks. He looks toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta approaches the function room, where pert  DEBBIE, wearing a JOHNSON FOR CONGRESS button, staffs a  felt- covered table. On  a nearby easel, a photo of a  silver- haired Man with a legend in blue and gold: JEFF   JOHNSON THE NAME YOU KNOW.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Eurotrash accent)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not too late, am I, dear? (extending a hand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, darling, Alma Preston, how are you today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for coming, Ms. Preston, I'm Debbie Bartle. (consulting a list)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do we have your check yet? Loretta pulls a Mont Blanc pen and a checkbook from her bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, honey, I don't think you do, we just got in last night from our place in Barbados -- how much is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five hundred a person.   Barbados?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (writing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, we're just down the beach from Mick Jagger and Jerry. (looking up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wouldn't turn down a couple of thousand, would you? A pleased smile from Debbie. Loretta opens the check- book, flashing the immense RING in front of Debbie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um, that's a lovely ring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92              4.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, thank you. I thought it might be a little gaudy...who should I make this out to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnson for Congress. It's not gaudy, it's just...nice and big.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's my Carlos...I can't even look in a store window. We're walking down this street in Rio, we pass a jewelry store...I didn't even turn my head and he's in the shop... (holds up ring)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...$250,000. I said it's crazy... but you know Carlos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish I did. ON Tommy watching Loretta. A Guest standing just behind Tommy -- wearing MRS. ZEKE BRIDGES name tag -- watches JEFF JOHNSON gladhand the room robustly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear they had him open for six hours. ZEKE, a very fat cigar-smoker, marvels at Johnson's appearance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chuckling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sum' bitch looks terrific. Tommy, eavesdropping, joins Zeke's chuckle, which unfor- tunately turns into a wheeze and then a cough. Zeke turns to Tommy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about taking our orders, son?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely my friend!    How can I pleasure you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bourbon straight up and a Perrier rocks for the lady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             5.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah! Fire and ice! Wonderful! But may I suggest you make that a double sir? After all, so many guests, so few of me -- who knows when I may be back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, why not. AT THE ENTRANCE LORETTA pauses before going into the room

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know where the powder room is, hon? I should freshen my face before I go in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just over there. ON JEFF JOHNSON with his well-groomed wife, VERA, and a barrel-chested Man in full resort wear, wearing an OLAF ANDERSEN name tag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So how the heck are you, Olaf?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should be asking how you are, congressman. Johnson pats his chest and smiles at Vera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This old ticker never felt better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's good to see you back on your feet, Jeff. We need you in Washington. Inconspicuously, a pretty young redhead whispers to Vera. This is JENNIFER, Johnson's Administrative Assistant (his AA).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's that granddaughter of yours, Olaf? Ready for the Olympics?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She'll be thrilled you asked after her. 8   IN THE HALLWAY Loretta emerges from the Ladies' Room. catches a spike heel... recovers her balance... then frantically searches her hands and clothes, SCREAMS, and gets down on hands and knees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             6.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God!    My God! Oh my God! Debbie rushes over to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hyperventilating)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My --   my ring. My diamond. I took it off   in the ladies' room to wash my hands.    I was just putting it on -- I must   have dropped it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting down)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me help you, we'll find it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call Security! 9   IN THE FUNCTION ROOM Tommy maintains his watch on Loretta. Zeke Bridges taps Tommy on the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, what about our drinks? Tommy instantly assumes an ANGRY YOUNG STREET BLACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?    What you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?    You already took our order.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That wasn't me! You must be thinking of Jamal. I'm Karim. What you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bourbon straight up and a Perrier rocks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snorts derisively)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hunh. He walks two steps...and once again makes no attempt to get the drinks. Zeke returns to Jeff Johnson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             7.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't get me wrong, Jeff. Pyramid Insurance doesn't want special breaks. I just think we ought to be able to set our own rates without Uncle Sam sticking his nose in our business. Johnson signals Jennifer to come over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know my AA? Zeke Bridges, this is Jennifer, my Administrative Assistant. Zeke's been a tremendous help to us. I'd like you to listen to his view on health insurance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd be very happy to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At Pyramid Insurance, we call our approach the Patient's Bill of Rights. 10   IN THE HALLWAY Loretta and Debbie are on hands and knees, still looking. A pair of shoes comes INTO FRAME. They LOOK up at a bullet-headed man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ms. Preston?   Bruno Handler, hotel security.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My ring!   My ring! Oh my god...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now just calm down, Ma'am... can you describe the ring?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a diamond ring! A big diamond ring! Oh my Christ! She's frantic.   Debbie takes Bruno aside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw it. It's huge... it must be like eight carats. She says it was a quarter of a million dollars! Bruno turns back to Loretta, trying to calm her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             8.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma'am... calm down.   Now, is the ring insured?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course it's insured! But you know how it works -- if I report it, they'll cancel me. And I don't want another ring! I need this ring! The ring Carlos gave me. Bruno turns, speaks into the walkie-talkie he's carrying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where the fuck is housekeeping? I called for those dickheads ninety seconds ago. 11   IN THE FUNCTION ROOM the Guests have gathered to hea Johnson speak. As Andersen introduces him, Tommy con- tinues eyeing Loretta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I won't run through Jeff's record -- he's been in Congress twenty years, and I've only got two minutes. I'll just say this: When those of us in pharmaceuticals, or agribusiness, or insurance, or (indicating himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: utilities, or you name it -- when we've needed him, Jeff's been there for us. And we've been there for Jeff, too -- we raised a hundred thousand dollars today! (APPLAUSE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without further ado, our man in Washington, Jefferson Davis Johnson. 12   IN THE HALLWAY Debbie hears the APPLAUSE (O.S.).   S gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should be in there. Good luck, Ms. Preston. I hope you find it. She leaves.   Loretta, mascara smeared, gets up, as does Bruno.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't go in there like this. God! Please... listen... I'll pay a ten thousand dollar reward for anybody who finds my ring. Just don't tell Carlos! (suddenly grim)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll kill me. THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            9. 13   IN THE FUNCTION ROOM, as Johnson takes questions, To slips out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you make of all this campaign reform business, Jeff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, y'know Ernie... these days, everyone's down on the political action committees and so-called special interests. But, heck, I think you and Fran have a right to participate in our democracy in exactly the way you're doing today. I'm in Congress to represent you. I don't want any so-called reform to take that power away from you. 14   APPLAUSE (O.S.). IN THE HALLWAY Bruno issues orders two Maintenance Men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want every heating grate opened and inspected. I want every air conditioning duct vacuumed. Do you understand what I'm saying? AS he speaks, Bruno SEES Tommy pass through the hallway ... spot something on the floor... pick it up... furtive- ly put it in his pocket... and walk rapidly toward the door to the kitchens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (running after him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you! Waiter! Hold it right there! Bruno puts an arm on Tommy. Tommy instantly assumes a frantic, wimpy, craven persona, along wth his CARRIBBEAN ACCENT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! Please! Do not report me! I will be deported!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Calm down.   What've you got in your pocket?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told the CIA everything! I agreed to poison the pineapples! My green card is in the mail!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             10.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stow it! I'm not Immigration, I'm hotel security. Now, what did you just put in your pocket?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm warning you, flathead, get cute with me and I will tear you a second asshole. Now a valuable diamond ring is mising...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valuable? We can almost see the light bulb click on above Bruno's head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very valuable. All right, I'll give you a hunnert bucks for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hundred and five? Bruno snorts agreement, goes for his wallet... Tommy goes gor the ring... then suddenly leaps back in a cringe!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! It's a trick! You will call me a thief and send me back and the Security Police will make me stand on my head in the guano pit! I have seen such things on

dialogues.speaker: CNN
dialogues.text: Bruno snaps and GRABS TOMMY BY THE COLLAR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, I'm not trying to trick you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no... it is a trap! I must turn this over to police. He starts to leave.   Bruno grabs him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92              11

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, dipshit... a valuable ring is missing and there's thousands of dollars in reward money waiting. So you'd better fork over...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How big is this... reward? Another lightbulb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um, five hundred dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said 'thousands.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.     Right.    A thousand dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, no...you said thousands. With an 'S'. This is plural. This means "two or more thousands."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (deep sigh)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, you win. Two thousand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or more.     Two or more. Bruno's had enough -- his grip tightens around Tommy's neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just making a point. 15   IN HOTEL LOBBY AT THE CASHIER'S DESK Bruno slides a check to the Cashier, who counts a stack of bills. Bruno picks up a house phone, dials.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ARMANDO, still unshaven, answers the RINGING phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? INTERCUT with Bruno in the lobby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, may I speak with Ms. Preston?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92              12

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's in the bathroom. This is Carlos. Can I take a message?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thanks, I'll call back. ARMANDO hangs up the phone and exits the hotel room. BRUNO crosses to the far side of the lobby, where Tommy waits inconspicuously. He gives him the money. Tommy gives him ring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now get back to work! As Tommy heads back to the function room, Bruno picks up a house phone, dials, listens. He dials again, listens. No answer. He dials the operator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Bruno in Security. Put me through to 502 -- there must be something wrong with the line, I can't get an answer... What do you mean, there's no one in 502? I just spoke to them!... No one's registered in 502? Are you sure?... Well, check again!... Shit! He hangs up, looks at the ring, and realizes he's been taken. His face twisting with rage, he hurries after Tommy. 17   ON TOMMY MOVING swiftly through the function room to an exit. Zeke Bridges grabs him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey!   Where the hell are our drinks. Surprised, Tommy opts for an EAST INDIAN ACCENT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember... you were the sloe gin fizz and the mango daquiri? With perhaps a small umbrella for the lady?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bourbon neat and a Perrier, dammit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And would you still be wanting the umbrella then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             13.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: As Zeke's face flushes in anger, Tommy SEES Bruno come into the room, blood in his eye. Tommy turns sharply and heads out the terrace doors to the --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommy conceals himself behind a pillar, across the court- yard, away from the Guests. But from another direction, Johnson and Andersen approach, arm in arm, and sit on a bench by the pillar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Olaf, there's something I wanted to sound you out on. As a special friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shoot. Tommy moves away from the pillar, sees Bruno roaming the terrace, and retreats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm thinking of retiring from Congress. Andersen's eyes widen in astonishment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm thinking maybe I won't run. Maybe I should listen more (indicating his heart)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: to this. Really appreciate these years. Sail around the world. Climb mountains. Enjoy the finer things of life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff. Listen to me. You can't retire. Florida needs you. I need you. I need you on rates. I need you on regulations. I need you on those environmental nutcases --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Olaf, if I retire this year, I get to keep all the money left over in my campaign treasury. Comes to a very tidy nest-egg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How tidy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             14.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One-point-three million. (chuckles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's called the grandfather loophole. Bruno has gone.   But Tommy stays.   His eyes light up at the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Jeff. Look at what you'd be giving up. Going to the best resorts in the world and calling it "official business." Golfing and skiing and fishing, and never picking up a tab. And, Jeff -- there's no aphrodisiac like power. You can have some of the most intelligent, attractive women in the country. You've got it made!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I suppose that one-point-three may seem like spare change to the head of Gulf Coast Power, but to a country boy like me --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Jeff. I get it. Look. There's a little software company that's about to go through the roof. Johnson smiles at the direction the conversation is taking. ON Tommy also smiling, in admiration at the transaction going down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few thousand worth of stock options would stand to make you quite a pile. As long as your blind trust buys them, you're clean -- the SEC can't shake a stick at you. Half a million, easy -- and that's just a start.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if you put it like that... I now see I have a duty to continue my career in public service. Johnson stands, puts his arm on Andersen. Tommy emerges, shakes his head, and laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm in the wrong business. THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A ramshackle bait shack, paint peeling, on the inland waterway. At the rear of the shack, Armando shoots hoops into a tattered net. Loretta, back in jeans, looks at her watch. A bondo-patched Econoline van pulls up. Tommy jumps out, big smile. He gives Loretta an energetic round of APPLAUSE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The best li'l roper in America! But she doesn't want the charm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You took your time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cops bust you, Tommy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Busted?   Moi?    Fuck no. He pulls out the wad of bills.       Their faces brighten considerably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That look like busted?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Washington, D.C.   The illuminated dome of the Capitol.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA ROAMS the well-hung walls. From the photos and memorabilia, we realize that we are in the office of Rep. Jeff Johnson. In the reflections on the frames, we GLIMPSE some MOVEMENT on the desk explaining the considerable BREATHING and MOANING (O.S.).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God.     Oh my God. Oh my... But then a strange GURGLING sound (O.S.) escapes from Johnson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... God. A silent beat.   Then a horrified CRY.      Jennifer rise INTO FRAME.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my god! THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            14B.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The congregation is SINGING. We SEE the widow Johnson. At her side, in the aisle seat, a powerful man with bushy eyebrows, about 60, in a three-piece suit and watch chain: congressman DICK DODGE. The HYMN ends. Dodge steps up to the pulpit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was my honor to serve in Congress with Jeff Johnson for a generation. No one could have been a better legislator. No one could have been a finer husband and father. And now -- He presses the tips of his fingers together and looks skyward, as if communing with his memory of the deceased.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now God has called his servant home. ANGLE ON Jennifer, in black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We will miss him. But we are grateful that his passing was so peaceful -- and so like him -- working late into the night at his desk, the consummate public servant.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Vera sneaks a look at Jennifer, who is poker-faced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the veranda of the gracious  home, mourners pay respects to the family. Dodge   puts a gentle hand on the widow's shoulder and draws  her aside. He throws a look at Jennifer, who joins  them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vera, I know you're still in shock from Jeff's... passing. But we have to talk about his seat. Vera stares at Jennifer.   She knows the score.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Johnson, if you'd like to discuss this in private --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can stay -- what's the difference?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vera, I'd like you to announce that you're going to run for Congress. Let a few days pass to show proper respect. But next week, I want to stand next to you at a press conference where you declare for Jeff's seat in the House.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Dick -- no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nothing to be afraid of, Vera. With your name, you can't lose. People around these parts are so used to voting for Jeff Johnson -- why, Mrs. Jeff Johnson would win in a walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dick, I was a Washington wife for twenty years. Twenty years of Potomac bullshit is plenty for one lifetime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vera, we're talking about becoming a Member of Congress. We're talking about a sure thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92              16

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry about running the office -- I'll be there night and day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure you would, dear. But I couldn't give you the same job satisfaction Jeff gave you. Jennifer, embarrassed, didn't know Vera knew.    Nor did Dodge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A retirement community in the Florida sunshine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: open. A supermarket shopping cart full of groceries, tied with a big bow, rolls out, pushed by Tommy. Loretta accompanies him. Tommy BUZZES at a door. It's answered by Tommy's GRANDMA, a limber lady in leggings and a bright top. She sees the groceries, kisses him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is very sweet of you, darling. But you shouldn't have done it. Where did you get the money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't want to know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommy and Loretta are watching the track results on the local tv news. Tommy, playing solitaire, shuffles bril- liantly. Grandma comes in from the kitchen, shaking her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did I end up with a thief for a grandson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grandma -- I told you.    I'm not a thief. I'm a con man.     An artist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But also a crook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             17.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I only con crooks, Grandma. You can't con an honest man. Only somebody who wants something for nothing. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the good Lord must have been fond of pigeons, because he made so many of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes I just wish you were more like your Daddy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean, dead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, smartmouth... I mean someone who made something of himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing at TV)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOOK...it's the ad! VIDEO...a cheap TV spot -- a busty blonde in a skimpy outfit tossing her hair and pouting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fake Swedish accent)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am Inga. I'm here from Sweden and I'm s-o-o lonely. I need a man...and so do my girlfriends. VIDEO...Scantily-clad babes to match the names.    Lorett speaks along with the V.O.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Maria, my hotblooded Spanish friend...Babette, the Parisian pussycat...and many others. So call the "Girls of Many Nations," at 1-900-555-NATO. SUPER:   CALL 1-900-555-NATO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Swedish accent)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what do you think of my accent, Grandma?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Compared to what? Loretta, why don't you go baste the turkey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92               1

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Loretta gets up and goes for the kitchen. We hear a high-pitched ELECTRONIC WARBLE. Tommy reaches into Loretta's purse and pulls out a cellular phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calls to Loretta)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See?      I told you TV advertising works. He opens the phone and speaks in a toneless, recording- like voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello...you have reached Girls of Many Nations. For Hot Blooded Italian Wildcats, press "one" now. (nothing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For Perky American Cheerleaders, press "two" now. (nothing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a Sultry Swedish Love Goddess, press "three" now... ("BEEP")

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He covers the mouthpiece and calls to Loretta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bingo! Loretta...guy wants to speak to Inga.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him to call back.      I'm basting. TOMMY grins mischievously and speaks into the phone in the husky voice of a SWEDISH WOMAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ja, this is Inga. Hello Paul... how are you tonight? You are feeling naughty? That's all right ...you have your what in a bowl of oatmeal? Yes, that is very naughty, and maybe a little sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Disgusting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             19.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh NO! It's my husband Lars. He's home early, I must go before ...you want to talk to Lars too? So you like to talk dirty out of both sides of your mouth. (normal voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, you are one twisted bastard! Laughing, he hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommy, please!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, grandma, just getting a third minute out of him. He clicks off the phone and slams it back into Loretta's purse. Loretta, meanwhile, has reappeared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You hung up on Paul? He's one of my best customers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe any relative of mine does that for a living.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon Gramma...it's only my voice. They never actually meet me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So my granddaughter talks dirty for a living and my grandson's a thief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's up, Grandma? Are you embarrassed to show my picture around the pool?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course I'm not. Look. She goes to her sewing basket and pulls something from it. She unfolds it: a long piece of needlepoint she's been working on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It spells out Tommy's full name:   Thomas Jefferson Johnson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             20.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look what these arthritic hands been doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make me proud of you, Tommy. Make me proud of the name you carry. In the silence between them that follows, we HEAR the tv.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Ned Grable, vice president and general manager of WFLA. We think Mrs. Jeff Johnson did the right thing in not running for the congressional seat left vacant by her husband's death. The editorial catches Grandma's attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff Johnson's name may still be magic. But it'll take more than the magic of name recognition to solve our region's problems. I'm Ned Grable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Name recognition. Lordy, what a notion. People have to be some boobs just to vote for someone because their name is Johnson. Tommy's eyes widen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember once back in Georgia, they even elected a dead man. His name was still on the ballot -- people were just used to voting for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you say, Grandma?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOMER, the proprietor of Homer's Pit Stop, wearing fuel- smeared overalls, is dieseling a Customer's boat down by the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer!    Get your ass over here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92               2

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Up by the racks of junk food and beer, and pails of fish slop, Tommy and Armando await Homer. In b.g., an older black gentleman plays checkers, solo. This is VAN DYKE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this about, jefe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta! Get off the damn phone!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This better be good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sarcastic mimic)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "This better be good." Loretta! ON LORETTA on the pay phone, moaning in Swedish ecstasy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, ya, ya, God, you're so big! (waving at Tommy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-oh, I have to go now, my husband Sven is home early... Tommy grabs the phone.   He pushes aside a protesting Loretta...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddammit, Inga, is it that pervert again! Damn! He smacks the receiver with his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into receiver)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, you little shit -- I just spent eight years in the joint, nobody talks to my woman like that! I got your adress, I got a machete, I got two Rotweilers... I'm gonna come to your house and tear your ass up! (hangs up, laughing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Tommy, what's so damn important?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I got work to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            21.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They all look at him expectantly. He takes a dramatic pause, then launches into a "Come to Jesus" speech.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My friends, I want to tell you about a town where the streets are paved with gold. This is a town where the marks give you money before you ask. A town where they take you to dinner after you fuck 'em. A town where when they need money, they just print more. This is a town where a guy bounced nine hundred checks and he didn't even have to skip town!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't no town like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean Vegas?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Washington, D.C.   I'm going to run for Congress. His big smile meets their blank surprise.   Their faces fall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this, a joke?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the con, Tommy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Van Dyke.   You remember Willie Sutton?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of blessed memory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You remember what he said? They asked him, Why do you rob banks? And he said, That's where the money is. I tell you, people -- Washington. That's where the money is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            22.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Tommy produces a sheaf of Xeroxes and pamphlets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I found this shit in the library. You know how much a congressman makes? A hundred and thirty a year -- and that's just base pay for getting your ass elected. Then there are these things called PACs, and these lobbyists, whose whole point in life is to buy you off. It's the con of a lifetime -- and the damn thing is, it's legal! This is hot, people, we can do this!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who "we," white man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never heard of staff, Armando? I get in, I get a staff allowance of five hundred and thirty-seven grand a year -- Loretta wolf-WHISTLES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- which I will generously share with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how exactly were you going to get your butt to Congress?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah -- why would anyone vote for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not for me, Homer. For Jeff Johnson. Name recognition -- that's what it's all about. You think folks know their congressman died? I get on the ballot as Jeff Johnson, I guarantee they'll vote for me. Now all's I have to do is get on the ballot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which is how?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92           23.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which is where you folks come in. (picking up a ream of forms)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All's we have to do is collect five thousand six hundred twenty five signatures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shittin' us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In your dreams, Tommy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You people got a better idea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Senior citizens fold brochures, stuff envelopes, make phone calls. Van Dyke and Tommy enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay... gimme the four-one-one on these Silver Foxes Again. It's a bunch of old folks who like to vote?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't laugh, they get an enormous turnout. But the big thing is, they have their own line on the ballot. They already got the signatures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lady we're meeting, Hattie Rifkin, they call her the condo queen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So all I have to do is snow one old lady. Don't sound like major surgery. THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            24.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommy and Van Dyke are seated opposite HATTIE RIFKIN, a high-energy woman, 70s, with a frizz of white curls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, what brings you here?   You want to talk politics... talk!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were wondering who you were going to run for Congress this year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, the usual sacrifical lamb. Probably Sylvia Roland. She just lost her husband, she needs to meet new people. Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Rifkin... I want to run.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I want to run too -- but with this plastic hip, it's not gonna happen. Tommy breaks up.   In spite of himself, he's charmed by t salty old babe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I mean is... I'd like to run for Congress on the Silver Fox ticket. I care about you and your issues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, that's what my son says. But does he call? Anyway, what makes you think a group of alter cockers are gonna support a man who hasn't clipped his first nose hair yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I can win.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no... a Democrat can win. A Republican can win. A Silver Fox can only make a symbolic point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. RIfkin, if you give me a ballot line, and if I can get support from...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            25.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If... if. Ven die bubbah halla tsehen qulishkes, het gehaya zadeh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, but... besser die viller ein der kenner. Hattie cracks up.   Tommy leans over and translates for Van Dyke:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She said, 'If my grandmother had balls, she'd be my grandfather.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (recovering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where the Hell did you learn to speak Yiddish?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same place I learned to hustle shtarkers at gin rummy. From Morris Elfbein... the Gin King of Miami Beach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No kidding... you knew the Rudolf Valentino of Dade County?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He taught me a great deal. He taught me you don't always need the best cards to win.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe not in gin, but in politics, young man, you need money to win, you need a name to win, you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I have a name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, you're an athlete, a movie star? I don't get out as much as I used to. You're not on MTV, are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No ma'am. My name is Johnson.      Jeff Johnson. The Name You Know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She ponders for a minute.    And then she gets it.   A wicked smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff Johnson. Well,     that's a name even our Alzheimer's    Group will remember. (beat; shakes    her head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still, for a full-up    campaign, we'd need materials, we'd    need ads...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You leave that to me, Mrs. R.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The widow Johnson is pouring tea for Tommy, now in super- nerd drag -- wire-rim glasses and tweed sport jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure I understand, Professor Franklin -- you wrote your doctoral thesis on my husband?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was a great man, Mrs. Johnson. He did so much for my people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He... did?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. I'll never forget when he said 'Welfare is a drug -- and you gotta kick it cold turkey.' It was... inspirational.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really... well, I'm sure...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I was actually in the audience when he said, 'If you people would just get off your dead asses and look for work, this country might be fit to live in again.' Powerful stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's very kind of you to say so. And you're very kind to come all the way from... where was it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            27.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wilson-Pickett State Teachers College. But I didn't just come to pay respects, ma'am. I came because your husband deserves an archive. A place where scholars can study his legacy. A storehouse for the record of his remarkable career.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see.   So you want... his papers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, not just his papers, Mrs. Johnson. Everything. Buttons, posters, bumper stickers. All the paraphernalia of his campaigns -- proof of his political genius. Now I realize that you may have a sentimental attachment to a few items...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take 'em all. Would you like the wedding photos, too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I don't think that's necess...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good -- that way you won't have to go rooting around in the garbage. Is there anything else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, um... no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More tea?   Or something stronger? I know it's  only ten-thirty, but, hell, sun's  over the yardarm somewhere,  right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, ma'am, I should be getting back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            28.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're in pretty good shape for a professor. D'you work out? Tommy rises and packs his briefcase hastily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I, um, have a class to teach. You know how blind students are... they're so dependent. (edges toward door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry ma'am... your materials will be in good hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: cuts the RE- off a RE-ELECT JEFF JOHNSON bumper sticker in familiar blue and gold. Van Dyke, Armando, and Homer have a production line going doctoring the old Johnson campaign materials, slicing off and painting out the RE-'s and the years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure you don't want to come to Washington with us, Homer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bums got time on your hands. (indicating bait shack)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got a business to run. ON LORETTA working the RINGING pay phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? Who? The League of Women Voters? Sorry, Mr. Johnson won't be attending the debate. No -- no, Betty, I'm sorry, I can't tie up this line. (hangs up; it RINGS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? The Sarasota Star-Ledger? I'm sorry, we're out of photographs. No, you can't, Mr. Johnson has just had surgery for a deviated septum. (hangs up; it RINGS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? (brightening)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ya, this is Inga. PAN TO TOMMY training a home video camera on a poster tha reads JEFF JOHNSON FOR CONGRESS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             29.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very white)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not going to show you Jeff Johnson waving a flag. We're not going to show you Jeff Johnson kissing babies. We're not going to show you Jeff Johnson doing anything, because you already know what Jeff Johnson can do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The poster fills the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow, vote for Jeff Johnson. The name you know. A very puzzled Vera Johnson watches the ad on tv.

dialogues.speaker: SERIES OF SHOTS
dialogues.text: The congressional district sleeps. But   in the darkness, a kind of D-Day onslaught is under way.   QUICK SUPER- IMPOSED CUTS of Tommy's secret army of  Silver Foxes, opening crates, fanning through parking  lots, swarming over lawns, driving in stakes, tacking  up posters everywhere. INCLUDE Tommy climbing a telephone pole... Armando shinny up a light pole across the street... Loretta and Van Dyke pulling on a rope... which hoists a huge bundle to Tommy. who opens and unfolds it... and gets an end through the air to Armando. They unfurl the biggest banner imaginable

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA TILTS DOWN. Every square    inch of town seems to have been plastered with JOHNSON   FOR CONGRESS material. It's on billboards, bumpers, bus   shelters, balloons, banners, utility poles... all in   the late congressman's signature design.

dialogues.speaker: QUICK SERIES OF SHOTS
dialogues.text: The Econoline, now a JOHNSON ad on wheels, ghetto-blaster mounted front and back on the roof, rolls by a Jewish del ...a soul food joint... a whitebread country club... a Chinese restaurant... At each, Tommy's amplified VOICE sa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             30.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff Johnson.    The name you know. In a different appropriate accent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In front of a polling place, Van Dyke pulls up in a hears with an ELECT JOHNSON banner. So, driving muscle cars, do Armando, Homer, and Loretta -- Tommy's get-out-the-vote f Exhilarated senior citizens pile out, led by Hattie.

dialogues.speaker: INT. POLLING PLACE
dialogues.text: An ordinary Couple, 40s, sign the registration book, then enter adjacent voting carrels. After a moment, the HUSBAND leans out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are we voting for Congress?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't we always vote for Johnson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it -- Johnson. HIS HAND punches the hole in the ballot next to Johnson.

dialogues.speaker: VIDEO
dialogues.text: A NETWORK ANCHOR at an election-night news set.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're just joining us, our exit polls project that in Florida, an unknown, independent candidate whose sole asset appears to be his name may just possibly win a slim victory.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: thru 42

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blinding lights. Media circus.     TV power cords, a huge tangle snaking back toward mobile   generators. Cameramen narrowly miss knocking each other   into the water. A STEEL DRUM BAND plays "Happy Days   Are Here Again."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             31.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The small crowd -- Tommy's cronies, their pals, and a jubilant contingent of Panthers led by Hattie -- lets out a great WHOOP.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that him? Tricia, I believe Congressman-elect Johnson is coming this way. For the first time, we see Tommy wearing a beautifully-cu suit. He's instantly engulfed by lights, cameras, and Supporters. An amazed CAMERAMAN, watching Tommy, whispers to a Produc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus -- he's not... white. I actually voted for the guy. I thought he was Jeff Johnson. Tommy jumps onto a bench.    APPLAUSE from his Supporters

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, thank you, all of you, for your help. Give yourself a round of applause. They do. As APPLAUSE continues (O.S.), CAMERA PANS from Reporter to Reporter to Reporter, their mikes bearing the call-letters of different channels. ON GRANDMA being interviewed. She wears a JOHNSON FOR CONGRESS button and speaks with manifest pride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never been so proud in all my life. He was always such a good boy...well, I think he meant well. Sometimes -- well he was a clean child. That's important, I think... PAN TO FLORIDA REPORTER #2 doing a stand-up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then in Massachusetts, there was a guy named Kennedy who got elected, but he wasn't really a Kennedy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             32.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lot of dead incumbents get re-elected, actually. It's an American tradition. ON Tommy. Speaking meaningfully, with great sincerity, he shows a gift for political discourse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We ran a positive campaign. We campaigned on the issues. The issue is leadership. Leadership for the future. Ask not what you can do for your country. The people have spoken. The only thing we have to fear is fear itself. If you can't stand the heat stay out of the kitchen. Live Free or Die. And in conclusion...read my lips! (APPLAUSE and CHEERS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommy looking out the window at the city below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The approach to National Airport gives a good view of Washington and its landmarks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The promised land.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The plane touches down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the airport move our Floridians. They look like they're going to opening day at the track.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congressman Johnson! Congressman Johnson! Tommy looks. It's REINHHARDT, a young straight-arrow bearing two huge document briefcases, which he puts down to shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92              33

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur Reinhardt. You remember me -- I Fed-Exed that material to you in Key West?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reinhardt, my man! Of course! You look just like I pictured you. Nice wing tips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Congressman, I hope you don't think I'm out of line for meeting you here -- I thought you might want some help with logistics, settling in at your hotel -- (indicating the briefcases)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since you didn't make it to the Harvard seminar, I put together a set of their papers for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like your initiative, Reinhardt, but to tell you the truth, I've never been much of a student. Maybe you can brief my staff sometime. Reinhardt looks Tommy's cronies over.     Not your classi Hill types.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But thank you, I will take you up on those logistics. Hey! Entourage! What hotel we at? They look at one another, puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reinhardt, it appears that the staff has neglected to nail down some details.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Jesus, the IMF's in town.    Where are we going to find a room?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four rooms.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92              34

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The entourage is enjoying a round of libations. Reinhardt runs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got lucky at the Madison. Thank god there's been a coup in Uruguay. Their delegation just checked out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a wizard, Reinhardt.    I knew you could handle it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommy's entourage and their luggage are being packed into a cab. Tommy turns to Reinhardt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So when does the House open for business? Reinhardt hasn't heard it put quite that way before. Reinhardt gets his courage up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, Congressman, you got my resume, didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hasn't a clue)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure I did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's something I wanted to ask you. I know it's a big step, but -- I'd like you to consider me to be your AA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's quite an offer, Reinhardt, very decent of you, but I'm just a social drinker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. AA. Your Administrative Assistant. I worked for Congressman Johnson. I'd like to work for you, Congressman Johnson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really. Tommy looks at his own troops, then back to Reinhardt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            35.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean like an affirmative action thing? Tommy opens the cab door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell you what -- I'll think about it, okay? Tommy gets in and closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through the open window)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for getting us settled, really appreciate it. (to driver)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madison Hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bridge over the Potomac has a classic view of the Lincoln Memorial and the Washington Monument. Their taxi drives by.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: & 54

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning. Tommy and cronies get out of a cab and bound up the grand flight of stairs. In b.g., the Capitol dome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk the superb ground floor corridor of Cannon, salivating. Marble columns... chandeliers... grand offices. Real class. AT AN ELEVATOR with a sign above it -- MEMBERS ONLY -- they stop. Tommy presses the button. The door opens. The seated ATTENDANT gets a load of this group. Especially Loretta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, folks, this elevator's for Members only.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             36.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's okay, they're with me. Sixth floor please. Cannon 609. I'm going to my office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said Members only.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am a Member. Now take us to six before I haul your ass in front of the committee on disrespectful behavior.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elevator don't go to six. You have to get off at five and walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking puzzled, they make their way up a drab stairwell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not classy. On one side of the hallway, the windows give out on a brutally ugly courtyard. On the other side of the hall are cages: windowless storage bins behind metal fences crammed with junk -- and an occasional xerox machine, Mr. Coffee, and pitiful staffer at a tiny desk. Tommy opens the door to 609.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommy's office is a small, dark garret, with dirty car- peting, bare shelves, and a pile of bulging canvas U.S. Mail bags.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait here. He heads further into the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Equally unattractive.   Perched on the desk:   Reinhardt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You again!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, congressman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this shithole?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             37.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gesturing, peeved)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (casual)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh -- you missed the freshman   lottery for offices. They assign them    by draw. You didn't show for the    draw, so you got the worst office in   Congress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I missed what lottery?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was all in the briefing books I mailed you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What else did I miss, Reinhardt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you hiring me, congressman? Tommy gives Reinhardt a good once-over, seeing him anew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're shaking me down, aren't you? Tommy laughs, then clasps Reinhardt's shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is fantastic, Reinhardt. I haven't been here five minutes, and you're shaking me down. God, I'm gonna love this town. You're hired, man. Just tell me what to do next. I don't want to miss out on any of the good shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dinner for new Members is tonight, at Union Station. Do you have black tie? BEGIN elegant, spirited classical MUSIC.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With its hundred-foot barrel-vaulted ceiling and grand windows, the magnificent Beaux-Arts station has been beautifully restored.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             38.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A big crowd slowly makes its way along a red carpet to the party. Tommy was born to wear a  tux. In his  lapel, a red-and- gold eagle pin. On his   arm, Loretta, in a dramatic shoulderless and nearly  backless gown, with three-quarte gloves. The other Women   in sight are far more conserva- tively dressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A STRING QUARTET provides the music. Tommy and Loretta linger uncertainly near the entrance. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's meet some natives. Tommy leads her over to two Men, 30s, excellent haircuts. Both wear pins. He extends a hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommy Johnson, how'd you do, nice party, heck of a railroad station, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rafe Simon, freshman from Tulsa. And this is Bo Chandler --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- from Lufkin, Texas. You must be the one who didn't come to Harvard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I couldn't, it was my Princeton reunion....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff Johnson? You're Jeff Johnson? The guy from Florida?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Bo)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rest of us are out there on the campaign trail, raising money, kissing ass, making speeches, dragging our butts from place to place -- and he slides in on pure name recognition!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            39.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He puts his face close to Tommy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me tell you something, Jeff. A tense beat.   Then Rafe breaks into a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuckin' brilliant. Bo winks at Tommy. Tommy

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Thank you both very much. (to Loretta)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't that nice, now, don't you think? (to Rafe and Bo)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Miss Loretta, boys. She extends a regal hand to each, Liza Doolittle at the ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do yo do.    How do you do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it's Tommy. My friends call me Tommy. "Jeff" is my... professional name. So what line of work were you boys in before you got elected? You lawyers or something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no, I did morning weather and traffic for KTOK in Tulsa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't remember me? I was a tight end for the Oilers -- my knee gimped out. The origins of the gentlemen's political success is not lost on Tommy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, stop by my reception after the swearing in tomorrow, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but don't you go to his reception before you go to my reception.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            40.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine, but I'm gonna be real offended if either of you miss my reception. They leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we have to have a reception. AT THE BUFFET, as Tommy and Loretta help themselves generously to oysters and champagne, they overhear TWO MEMBERS passing by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So then I ran an ad calling him a draft dodger, but then he ran an ad calling me a plagiarist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, leaked a rumor that his father- in-law was a Nazi. I went up ten points in a weekend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Loretta)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're in the majors, doll. 62A   THE BALCONY is full of people working one another. Tommy and Loretta pass some large stone statues, a man extends his hand -- liquor lobbyist KEN KORNGOLD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congressman? I'd like to introduce myself. Ken Korngold. National Distilled Spirits Association.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommy Johnson. Distilled Spirits, is that right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's super that you won, congressman. Any way we can help, please don't hesitate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pleasure's all mine, Ken, hope you can make it to my reception. Do you happen to have a card?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             41.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (giving him one)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I sure do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommy is along a wall where other guests are similarly occupied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You now what I love about this place? The way everyone calls you a Member.  Every time I hear that, it makes me think of Mr. Happy here. The Member next to him bursts out laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you be peeing on my shoe. They go to the sinks.    The Member introduces himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike Strangland. Iowa -- first CD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a CD?    Shit, I missed that, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First Congressional district.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ohhh. Tommy Johnson. Florida. So Iowa -- how'd you get to Washington? You do the crop report on tv? IOWA has a big open face and a flat Midwestern voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- I owe it all to the Vietnamese.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: War hero?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: P.O.W. When I got back to Cedar Rapids, I spent so many years telling the Rotary Club what was wrong in Washington, they finally told me to put up or shut up -- so I put up. And here I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92              42

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. What's wrong in Washington?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon -- there's acid rain killing fish, and no one's stopping it... there's topsoil washing away, and no erosion program... there's chemicals in our livestock -- God, I sound like a Boy Scout.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's alright, Iowa -- this place could use a few geeks like you.

dialogues.speaker: TABLE
dialogues.text: Tommy shakes hands around the table, taking business cards as he goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete Slocum.   Asbestos Information Institute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike Gustofson. Freedom to Advertise Coalition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul Zeckhauser. American Tobacco Council.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey... thank you... nice to see you... hope you can make it to my reception. Have y'all met Miss Loretta? TOMMY'S TABLEMATE is lawyer-lobbyist TOMMY O'CONNOR, 40s. As Waiters serve lobster bisque, he hands TJ a business card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommy O'Connor. Soon as I saw how you got elected, I knew you were a real comer. Hell, I bet old Olaf Andersen voted for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's Olaf Andersen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             43.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: O'Connor points.    ON THE DAIS, Andersen is engrossed wi Dodge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't tell him you asked. Chairman of Gulf Coast Power. Constituent of yours, client of mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pays the rent, know what I    mean? Say, could I host a little    welcome- to-Washington thing for you    down at my law firm? Meet some of     my clients, five hundred a head -- you    could pick up twenty, twenty-five    grand to get you started.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cautious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how much of that do you get?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (amused)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh,    it doesn't come off the top. Down    the road, I'll bill 'em each five    hundred an hour whenever I take    you to lunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommy, I think this is the beginning of a beautiful relationship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: making a speech from the dais.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tonight we unite the two great pillars of our system -- political and financial. To the forty-four newly-elected Members of Congress, I say, Look around you tonight. Look around, and be thankful for the generosity. Tommy inspects the sea of barracudas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            44.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The people you see not only provided tonight's hospitality. They are the people you serve. That's our system of checks and balances at its best. Their support helped get you elected... your work will help them... and their support will help you in your next campaign, which I remind you is already less than two years away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In b.g., the Capitol dome. As Tommy and Loretta leave, they pass Dick Dodge, who is saying goodnight to guests. He stops them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, Mr. Johnson, it's customary for new Members to pay a courtesy call on the old fogies in the leadership. Especially from their HOME STATE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I would have, but I just got to town. It's an honor to meet you, sir. A real privilege. This is Miss Loretta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Public liaison. She pronounces the word so carefully, it sounds lewd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you    do? (to    Tommy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could    make up for it by having a nightcap    with me. (to    Loretta)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I have    my car take you home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommy and Dodge walk up steps toward the Capitol.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A darkened hallway. A hand-lettered sign by a door reads COMMITTEE ON POWER AND INDUSTRY. THE CHAIRMAN. MR. DODGE. Tommy and Dodge approach. As Dodge unlocks the door:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            45.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Mr. Chairman, but this ain't no homo shit we up to, is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  No, it's not. But -- (amused)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good thinking, Johnson. I'm impressed by your instincts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A single table lamp lights Dick Dodge's office, reflectin off the velvet drapes, sculpted ceiling, and crystal chandeliers. Tommy and Dodge are in leather armchairs, ties undone. On the table between them, a bottle of Jim Beam. Dodge casts a cool eye on Tommy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me, Johnson. Why did you come to Washington?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... of course... it's a chance to do something for my country. I mean, there's the topsoil thing, and acid rain is killing the cattle --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cut the bullshit, Johnson. I saw how you got elected. Flukes like you are either nutcases or troublemakers. I just want to know which one I have on my hands. Who sent you here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one sent me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You pulled off that upset on your own?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (acknowledging modestly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kid's got his talents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm impressed, Johnson, I am.     But why did you run for Congress?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No bullshit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92              46

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Opportunity knocks.    This town is the fuckin' Yukon. A stunned silence from Dodge -- then deep and generous laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a refreshing answer. He laughs again, richly amused.   Tommy joins in the laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shining in the bright sun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hundreds of business cards. An expert riffle, a one- handed cut, and Tommy deals lightning fast, a perfect diamond formation with two cards in the middle. He turns them over one at a time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Food... drinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reads card)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ken Korngold, National Distilled Spirits Association. Bob Rafferty ...Wisconsin Cheese Board. (to Tommy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want me to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're on cheese. I'll handle booze. He reaches for the phone...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pan from Capitol Hill to gleaming glass office building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking the phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ken! Ken Korngold! Tommy Johnson here... Right -- last night. How's it going, big guy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congressman! THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            47.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Expensive furniture, rugs, and art.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you on this helluva fine day! I'm looking forward to your reception.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, that's why I'm calling, Ken. You said if I needed some help --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You name it, congressman. Issue papers, testimony, floor speeches --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell you what I have in mind. I was just thinking, wouldn't it be a plus for old Ken Korngold if I was to -- how should I put this -- showcase some of his distillers' products at my reception? You know, like they put Reese's pieces in E.T.? It's called "product placement." People come in, they have a tremendous time, they see your products, they think well of you -- and they think well of me, too. It's good for both of us, Ken. What do you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's a new one on me, but hey, sure, I think we can help you out.  Say, while I have you on the line, there was one thing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SPEAKER administers the oath of office to the assembled House.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you solemnly swear that you will support and defend the Constitution of the United States... ON GRANDMA next to Tommy, eyes welling with pride. It's the one day a year that non-Members (meaning families) can be on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92              48

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... against all enemies, foreign and domestic; that you will bear true faith and allegiance to the same...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The 435 Members (with family) taking the oath, watched on C-span by Loretta, Armando, Van Dyke, and Reinhardt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... that you take this obligation freely, without any mental reservation or purpose of evasion...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON IOWA taking the oath, his toddler in his arms.     PAN along faces of other Members... to Tommy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and that you will well and faithfully discharge the duties of the office on which you are about to enter. So help you God?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congratulations. You are now Members of Congress. Sustained APPLAUSE.   Tommy kisses Grandma. INTERCUT Tommy's cronies APPLAUDING. ON THE FLOOR Tommy dries Grandma's tears with a finger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just that -- I'm so happy you straightened out. Tommy smiles ambiguously. As APPLAUSE continues, his eyes roam the room and make contact with Dick Dodge, standing at one of the leadership tables. Tommy winks conspiratorially at him. There's such diabolical glee in it, it even takes Dodge aback.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beautiful black woman, 20s, walks briskly down the busy Cannon corridors. CELIA. There's intelligence in her eyes, and fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            49.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She makes her way down the corridor, exchanging AD LIB greetings, glancing in at the sedate receptions, and drawing closer to the source of the REGGAE (O.S.) -- Tommy's office. She looks in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
