dialogues.text: It's packed, mainly with men.  Everyone has drinks and talks noisily. It looks like  a fraternity smoker for lobbyists. MUSIC comes from  a boom box. The bar -- a tablecloth over some desks -- is lavishly stocked. So are the bookcases, which now look like liquor store shelves. ANGLE ON LORETTA, in a cocktail dress and a HELLO MY NAME IS MISS LORETTA badge, staffing a little table, handing Celia a name-tag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Celia's hands print CELIA KIRBY.    PRO BONO. BACK TO SCENE - ON Tommy and Reinhardt talking with a LOBBYIST.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's an informal breakfast. You give us your views, we give you bacon and eggs, plus a couple of thousand dollar honorarium. (winking)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For your favorite charity. Tommy looks at Reinhardt, who explains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Tommy Johnson Foundation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (savoring the word)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honorarium. I like that. Loretta appears with a platter of food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Herring, gentlemen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, no thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? We've got it in cream sauce and in wine sauce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            49A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'll pass. Tommy steers her aside and takes a roll of soggy, toothpick-impaled herring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this?    Where's the cheese?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cheese guy didn't return my call. So I called the guy at the American Smoked Fish Institute. She points at the food table. There's nothing but a few boxes of crackers and two huge mounds of herring -- one white, one pink. The centerpiece is a large smoked fish, eyes staring accusingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, that's just wonderful. Sixty heavy hitters drop in, and I'm feeding 'em cat food. He breaks off, as Celia comes into view in the doorway behind. Tommy picks her up on his radar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll talk about this later. We follow Tommy through the crowd until he reaches Celia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi   there. Glad you could make it. So   you're... Celia Kirby. That's an   extremely beautiful name. For an   extremely beautiful woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow! That's smooth. After ten straight hours on my feet making small talk and breathing cheap cigar smoke, that's exactly the kind of line I'm ready to fall for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa, slow down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, sure, forget it. Can you just tell me, which one's Congressman Johnson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            49B.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if I said... me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. I see. So tell me, Congressman, just how deep is the shit I'm standing in? Tommy has to laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry about it. Why don't we just start over again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Celia Kirby. I'm the legislative director of Pro Bono.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah. Pro Bon. That's an extremely beautiful name. For an extremely beautiful organization. Um... what is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (amused)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're a public interest research and advocacy group. I'd like to brief you on our priorities this session. Can I call your AA to get on your schedule?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you brief me over dinner tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want an appointment, Congressman, not a date.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, sure, we'll type it up on the schedule, it'll be an appointment, except with wine and flowers on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks.   I really should be going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Won't you at least stay for a drink and some herring?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             49C

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid I'm busy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well then, can I tempt you with a smelt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks. (extending her hand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you. I'll be in touch with your office. I especially look forward to hearing your view on extending the sexual harassment law to include congressmen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love the way you say that. She slips out through the sea of revelers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fine Washington morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rep. ELIJAH MARSHALL, 50s, black, and a pain in Dodge's ass, is shaking hands and saying goodbye to some Constituents. Dodge approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 3/25/92            50.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard in the steam room you're going to try to screw up my ethics bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not screw up.    Amend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Eli, your amendments don't have a chance in hell to pass. My bill isn't perfect, I know, but it'll pass. And the President'll sign it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Isn't perfect"? Dick, your bill's the Incumbents Protection Act! How can you even call it an ethics bill?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because the public wants an ethics bill! So that's what we call it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it's got no teeth! It won't change a thing, and you know it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Eli, you're a politician, too. The less you're going to do about something, the more you have to talk about it. You know that. They start walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see. We close the bank, we stop the rubber checks, we raise the prices in the barber shop, we stop fixing parking tickets, and abracadabra! We say we've cleaned up Congress. Well, I don't think the American people want what this place has become.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the beauty of it! They must, Eli -- they keep re-electing us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not anymore! This new Congress is full of new faces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            51.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I wouldn't read too much into that. A few extra retirements, some redistricting -- nothing more than that. It's still business as usual up here. Dodge takes his glasses from his pocket and wipes them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I live in the real world, Eli. Do you? What's unemployment up to in your district? Eight percent? Eight-five?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eight point six.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Power and Enterprise is about to fund a solar demonstration plant, Eli. It could mean a whole lot to a district -- new jobs, new construction -- that interest you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't bribe me, Dick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dodge and Marshall enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli, the people who elected you. They sent you here to help them. Don't you want to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not  if it means supporting your bill. All  you want is the perfect platform to  campaign for Speaker. Dick Dodge. Mr.  Clean. What a joke!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (undeterred)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on board, Eli. (leaning in)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know -- you can't save the world if you can't save your seat. Tommy enters.   Marshall gives him a once-over and extend a hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            52.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We haven't met. Eli Marshall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommy Johnson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. The Florida upset. Well, now that you're here, what are you going to do with it? You gonna feather your own nest, or are you gonna make something of your office?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I plan to be as good a congressman as all the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly what does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, ever since I got back from Nam, I've wanted to do something about the rain forest --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, do me a favor, don't tell me. I try not to get depressed until the second week of a new session.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ushering Tommy into his office)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli, you'll excuse us -- we have a meeting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnson, I'm the chairman of a committee up here called Power and Industry. We've got an open seat, and I was wondering if you'd consider filling it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this good news?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92              53

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tongue in cheek)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it is a difficult assignment -- look at what we cover: energy, health, telecommunications, environment... the committee is constantly beset by a swarm of special interests. These are powerful people, they've got all the money in the world, and they're not shy about using it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So... this is very good news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most members would give their right nut for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what do you want from me, Dick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congressman... I just want you to smile for the cameras.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The committee members -- all white males, except Tommy -- mill around, awaiting the start of the hearings. As the TV cameras whir, Dodge shakes Tommy's hand warmly. Big smiles and an explosion of flashbulbs. Dodge breaks off and Tommy drifts over to Reinhardt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating dais)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, Congressman, welcome to the honey pot. You should be one happy freshman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? Well, I'm not. I'm suspicious. One thing I've learned is, when somebody gives you something for nothing, the nothing ain't nothing. It's something. What is it? Why me? Reinhardt puts his hand on Tommy's shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92               5

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congressman, I don't want you to take this the wrong way, but... you're black. And I mean that in the nicest possible way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dodge wants to run for Speaker. And he ain't gonna make it without votes from the black caucus. Suddenly, Dodge reappears.   He throws his arm around Tommy's shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommy, someone I want you to meet... Dodge steers TJ to a preppy-looking man at the witness table -- BARCLAY "SKEETER" WARBURTON.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skeeter, do you know Tommy Johnson? Meet the new member of the committee. Tommy, this is Barclay Warburton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pleased to meet you, Barclay. WARBURTON'S voice is aristocratic, a la George Plimpton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skeeter. Please. Been called that since boarding school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skeeter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damned fine to meet you. As Dodge and Tommy head for the dais, Tommy imitates Warburton's lockjaw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Tommy. Please. Been called that since reform school." Dodge chuckles, shakes his head in mock rebuke. Tommy takes his seat at the lower dais, smiles at the Members on his left and right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             55.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ON THE UPPER DAIS, Dodge gavels...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This EPA oversight hearing of the Committee on Power and Industry will come to order. I'd like to welcome our first witness, the distinguished Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency... (Warburton nods)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... but before I do, I note that a new Member is joining us today, the distinguished gentleman from Florida. THE BIGGEST EXPLOSION OF FLASHES YET... and as the motor drives whir, Tommy flashes his biggest smile yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommy's office walls are now richly hung with plaques, awards, and framed photos. We see he has been named the PESTICIDE COALITION'S Man of the Month. The winner of the NATIONAL RIFLE ASSOCIATION'S Achievement Award. The MOTION PICTURE ASSOCIATION OF AMERICA'S Outstanding Young Legislator. Etc. The liquor is gone. Loretta is at the receptionist's desk.   A LOBBYIST enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning. Ron Yaeger. Snack-PAC -- Snack Foods Political Action Committee. I have a ten o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please have a seat. The congressman is running just a little bit late. He sits and opens his briefcase. Van Dyke approaches him with the dignity of a superb butler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you care for some herring?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommy rises to speak at a breakfast meeting. The podium bears the seal of the American Poultry Association.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            56.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me start with a confession. I don't know much about poultry. But I do know something about people. And let me tell you: I like you people. So when you have something to say about poultry, I listen. Thank you very much. He sits down to generous APPLAUSE. ON Armando, in attendance, CLAPPING, marveling at the response TJ gets.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Capitol Hill is actually two worlds: the aboveground buildings that visitors and television cameras see, and the catacombs, the busy tunnels and corridors connecting the congressional office buildings and the Capitol. They're surprisingly unglamorous -- exposed pipes, white- washed brick walls, dumpsters, pizza carry-outs -- and through them move the legislators and their staffs. And here is Tommy, whistling ZIPPEDY DOO DAH. He loves this place. Passing a snack bar, he greets the Cashier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My man. He blows a kiss to a pretty Teller in the credit union. Passing the barber shop, he calls out to the Shoeshine Guy. He passes a black TELEPHONE MAN at an open panel of wires.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommy!    What's up, man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sweet Sue. Third race at Santa Anita.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several lobbyists are now awaiting Tommy balancing plates of herring on their knees. Some are enjoying it more than others. Tommy breezes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, how you folks doin', good to see you, Van Dyke making you comfortable? Tommy hits a button on a tape deck, turning on some EASY LISTENING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            57.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be with y'all shortly. BEHIND THE DIVIDER, outside Tommy's office door, Tommy ha a word with Reinhardt. Tommy indicates his office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She in there? Reinhardt nods.   Tommy gives himself a couple of squirts Binaca.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stick around for this, Reinhardt. I've finally figured something out about the women in this town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommy and Reinhardt meeting with Celia and an elfin guy in corduroy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for seeing us, congressman, we won't take up much of your time. This is Ira Schecter, our research director.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, good to meet you, you folks know Reinhardt, don't you? Don't rush, Miss Kirby, we can take as long as we want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you have people waiting, and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all right. They can wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well. She pulls documents from her briefcase and hands them to Tommy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are issue papers. This session we're targeting auto insurance premiums, child safety, and food additives.   As votes come up, we know you'll be hearing plenty from the other side. We'd just like a clean shot at making our case, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            58.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, we'll follow up with your staff in the next week or...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute, you just got here. I clean my calendar, and you're out the door. Let's back up, give this stuff the attention it deserves. Car insurance... Ira, what do you pay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I've got an '85 Plymouth, about six-fifty a year...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six-fifty? Highway robbery! A chop shop wouldn't give you more than a hundred forty for a junker like that. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or so I've heard. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'm flying blind here, I need depth. Could Miss Kirby put together a briefing? Maybe schedule a Saturday or two to really dig into the issues?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised and pleased)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... we'd be delighted. We've got some figures that will amaze you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure you do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we won't take up any more...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa, whoa, hold on, what about child safety?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we're sponsoring a bill imposing safety standards on imported toys...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92               5

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great! About time! I     hate imported toys. What about food    additives? How about we block out   a few evenings, you can take   me through the details.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Celia, if that's what the Congressman wants... any problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to do this in the evening?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm away for the next two weeks. She gives him a look.    Ira turns to Tommy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, when can Celia start your briefings?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saturday night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saturday night sounds fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. Wednesday morning.      Nine- fifteen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On a door in the House sub-basement:    MEMBERS ONLY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The regular evening pickup basketball game. Even among these ruthless players, Tommy's street moves are outstand ingly down and dirty. His principal accomplice: Elijah Marshall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A standing poker game among the towel- and robe-clad Members. It's Tommy's shuffle and deal.    He is convincingly awkw A BULLDOG of a man examines his hand, tosses two cards in He assembles his new hand. Four fives and an ace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92               6

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ON Tommy's hand.   A pair of threes. The betting starts, at a couple of chips, and comes round to Tommy. He pushes a stack of chips to the center.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get serious, fellas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommy, Marshall, and the Bulldog, back in suits, exit the MEMBERS ONLY door and move through the catacombs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need your help on the ethics bill, Leon. I want you to co- sponsor my amendments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You make a persuasive case, Eli.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That wasn't a yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (courteously ambiguous)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I promise to give it the attention it deserves. The Bulldog gives Tommy a friendly squeeze --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better luck next time, son. -- and leaves them.   Tommy and Marshall continue on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He took six hundred dollars off you that last hand, didn't he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, he's taking a real shine to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I didn't know better, I'd say you lost to him on purpose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing wrong with letting the chairman of the ethics committee roll you once in a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92           60A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You fit in real well up here.   Too well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So Eli, how come you haven't asked for my help with your amendments?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give it a rest, Tommy. You've got a great jump shot. But everyone knows you're Dick Dodge's boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bristling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm nobody's boy, mister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (weary)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't waste your outrage on me. I know what you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm no different from anyone else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not true. Some people here actually try to do something besides save their own ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, Eli, I like you, I really do. You remind me of my father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, really?   How so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He thought I was scum, too. BELLS begin RINGING and LIGHTS FLASHING on all the clocks and sconces down the corridor. Three RINGS, pause, three RINGS, pause... Marshall does a U-turn. Tommy doesn't follow suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you going to vote?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating clocks)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vote? Is that what that is? We got a pool going in the office on when it'll go off next. THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            60B.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's called "Gucci Gulch." The lobby just outside the doors to the House chamber is pandemonium -- a sea of lobbyists, lawyers, PACmen, Members, and staffers urgently trying to find their masters and signal them thumbs-up or-down. Tommy enters, sweeps the room with his eyes, looking for Reinhardt, shrugs, then goes through the doors onto the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommy goes to a console on the rear of a seat. A blue light says OPEN. Tommy inserts a card (it looks like an electronic hotel key). Red, green, and amber lights at buttons labeled NAY, YEA, and PRES. Tommy shrugs, pushes NAY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Tommy heads away, he passes a class trip -- a dozen fifth-graders and their TEACHER, who hails him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me -- Congressman? Do you have a moment? We're from the Hawthorne Avenue School, in Union, New Jersey? I'm Mrs. Kozlowski. Social Studies. We were just learning how a bill becomes a law. (indicating the BELLS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was that a vote?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, it was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what did you vote?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I voted "Nay." It's a terrible bill. It'd destroy the fabric of American life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what was the vote on? Tommy hasn't a clue. He calls out to Rafe, who is among those leaving the chamber.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Rafe! Tell these kids what that vote was about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             61.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to kids)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guy's got a real knack for explaining things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it was a motion to reconsider the motion to reconsider. Bo, passing by, intervenes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it was the rule on amending the reauthorization.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which means?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clean Air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (overlapping)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: School lunches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're in excellent hands, kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A NOISY restaurant popular with lobbyists. Power photos on the wall. Table hopping. People SHOUTING greetings across the room. Waiters in long aprons. Tommy is having lunch with Tommy O'Connor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a gentleman, Tommy. We can always do bid'ness -- I like that in a Member.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Tommy. I love you too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, I'd like to do more money for you -- I just need to know your positions on a few issues. O'Connor takes out a pen and leather notecard case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For instance, where are you on sugar price supports?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            62.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Tommy has no idea, but he's certainly open to suggestions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sugar price supports. Where do you think I should be, Tommy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit -- makes no difference to me. If you're for 'em, I got money for you from my sugar producers in Louisiana and Hawaii. If you're against 'em, I got money for you from the candy manufacturers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You pick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (writing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's put you down as for. Now what about putting limits on malpractice awards?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You tell me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if you're for 'em, I got money from the doctors and insurance companies. If you're against 'em, I got money from the trial lawyers. Tell you what, let's say against. Now how about pizza?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating his plate)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll stick with the salad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not for lunch, shmuck, for PAC money. A lot of the frozen pizzas use phony cheese. There's a law pending requiring them to disclose it on their labels. Where do you stand? Tommy thinks it through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I vote for the labels...then I get money from the dairy industry...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92          63.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if I vote against the labels, I get money from the frozen food guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excellent! And don't forget the ranchers, because they get hurt if pepperoni sales go down!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing in admiration)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pepperoni lobby. I love this town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So which is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck the cheese people. Thanks to them my office smelled like smelt for a week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.    For.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So Tommy, tell me -- with all this money on every side, how does anything get done?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't!    That's the genius of the system!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A briefing in progress. Flip charts, ring binders, Celia, Ira, a couple of other Pro Bono types. Tommy is riveted by Celia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It comes down to a question of what is acceptable risk. Are we willing to feed our kids a substance that causes cancer in lab rats? More important, who gets to make the decision? Bureaucrats and big corporations, or the people whose lives depend on it? THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            64.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommy's staff shares one small office.   Everyone's on th phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Willie? Congressman Johnson is calling. Can you take his call? Thank you. Please hold. Van Dyke puts him on hold, counts to three, gets back on the line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Mr. Willie, he just picked up another call. Listen, I know why he was calling -- he hasn't heard from you about his fundraiser... PAN TO Armando.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... That's right, Mr. Brown, on the thirtieth... A thousand a couple...A whole table? He'll be so happy to hear it. Thank you so much. (calling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta! Put down nuclear power for ten g's. PAN TO Loretta, who chalks the figure onto a toteboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cool. (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Newburg? It's Miss Loretta, from Congressman Johnson's office, how you doin'? On Loretta's bulletin board is a map of the United States with flags, pushpins, and air travel routes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, the congressman's going to be out your way next week... Palm Springs, the Bob Hope Classic -- yes, a celebrity player. As long as he's on the coast, we were wondering whether you aerospace people might want to lay on a lunch so you can hear his views... Uh-huh ... Uh-huh... Lovely. Now what kind of contribution to his foundation you folks thinking about? THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92              65

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Celia continues her briefing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...And in the 1988 study, it was up to eight per hundred-thousand. Um...am I losing you on these mortality rates?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I was just wondering how much of this is a statutory problem, and how much is a regulatory one? I mean, didn't the Merton Act cover most of this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmmm, that's an excellent point. Let me see something... As she starts rummaging in her briefcase, we TRACK AROUND to a COMPUTER SCREEN on Tommy's desk -- it displays THE EXACT WORDS HE'S JUST SPOKEN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow...you're right. Maybe we can get them to amend Merton-Simmons. RACK FOCUS...reveals REINHARDT in b.g., sitting at another computer terminal. He is typing in Tommy's responses, which appear on Tommy's screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, for Merton to apply you have to show high contagion...sounds to me like your contagion rates are no higher than the common clod. In b.g., Reinhardt DIVES FORWARD to his keyboard and begins correcting his typo. Celia looks puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Common cold. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must have picked up a little dyslexia over the weekend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see. Well, I must say I'm pretty impressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're also impressively pretty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92           66.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Celia is startled. Tommy is embarrassed...the dumb compliment he's just spoken was one Reinhardt typed on the computer screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh come on...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right. Sorry.      Excuse me a second. (calls out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur? Without explanation, he THROWS HIS PENCIL hard out of frame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ow!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A jet flies through the sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommy and handful of other Members listen to their GUN LOBBYIST host.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frankly, we    think the semi-automatic has gotten a    bad rap. That's why the American    Sporting Gun Users PAC put together    this trip. ON TOMMY AND DODGE enjoying champagne and hors d'oeuvres.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommy, wearing full L.L. Bean drag, wading with the other Members. Someone blows a shrieking DUCK CALL. A flock takes flight Everyone in the group raises their weapons: AK-47s. A burst of GUNFIRE. Rambo time. We SEE the flock still flying. One duck drops at the feet of the hunters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must have had a heart attack. THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92              67

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP IRON INSTITUTE CELEBRITY PRO-AM.
dialogues.text: Tommy tees off. He is wearing a veritable pro     shop of custom golf gear, all emblazoned with logos of    corpora sponsors and lobbies. He hits the ball about     200 yards...but more or less perpendicular to the    hole. REVEAL BOB HOPE standing nearby, watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew all these congressmen get a slice, but I didn't know it was that big.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommy on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you miss me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Celia at her desk in the somewhat ratty Pro Bono offices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did you go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, a fact-finding mission, some issue conferences, a few speaking engagements, a charity event... the usual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More like the Petroleum Institute Ski Cup, the NRA Open, the --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey.    Have lunch with me tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't -- we're having a press conference.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it -- the ozone layer?     No fault? Killer apples?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            68.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toy safety. Wait a minute. Tomorrow's Friday. Aren't you back early?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beaming)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You remembered! That means you missed me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommy and Celia walk over the bridge to the cherry trees by the Tidal Basin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, how'd you end up hustling for Pro Bono instead of pesticides? I mean, you could have been a big- time lawyer, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I was for a while.   It... depressed me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At a hundred grand a year, how depressed can you get? Doesn't it depress you to lose all the time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes. Mostly it gets me angry. And the anger keeps me going. Sure, I wouldn't mind winning a few. And it's not like I'm allergic to money...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So why do you do it? She skips a stone on the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, it's so embarrassing to come out and say it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meaning. I need my life to mean something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92               6

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: This actually hits Tommy.    Celia, embarrassed, changes the subject.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My question is, how'd you get named after a Memorial?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grandma like Jefferson. Y'know, "Life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness." It's a lot to live up to, so I specialized in the last part.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how's the pursuit going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine...'til I met you. Now...the better I do, the worse I feel. They have stopped walking.    They are standing close together. They kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So...when can I see you again? How about dinner Saturday night? She shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about Sunday morning?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brunch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the pulpit, Rev. Elijah Marshall thunders:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wages of sin is death! And to the man who values Gold over Goodness...the Lord allows no exemptions! REVEAL TOMMY and Celia in the front pew. Marshall appears to be preaching directly to Tommy, who wears a slightly sick smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To the man who shows no respect for the privilege of walking this Earth, God allows no deductions!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            70.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (AMEN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And to the man whose pockets are bulging and whose soul is empty... the Lord grants no 90-day extension! (AMEN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And when the last trump sounds, believe me, you will be audited!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (aside to Celia)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is one hell of a date.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the steps, Marshall shakes hands with his Congregants. Tommy and Celia exit the church. Marshall takes Celia by the hands and kisses her familiarly. Tommy is taken aback.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, darling. Glad you could make it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I liked the sermon, Uncle Eli.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncle Eli?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My niece says you're not half as slimy as I thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your niece?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would put you somewhere between a lizard and a toad. Quite a step up. Tommy looks from Marshall to Celia and back again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could I have missed the family resemblance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHISTLING happily, Tommy rounds the corner and heads to his office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92           71.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Ahead of him, encamped in the hallway, he sees a phalanx of SENIOR CITIZENS, many carrying placards, and some camera crews. Tommy adjusts his tie, turns on the charm, and approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ladies! Looking good!   How can I help you folks today! But Hattie Rifkin and her troops will have none of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't "Ladies!" me, you dick! The camera lights go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now let me get this straight. You voted to make people on Medicare pay more money to their doctors?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Medical Association made a persuasive case. Ten grand from their PAC, plus Christmas in Aspen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommy -- if I'm not mistaken, you wouldn't be here without the good senior citizens of your district. You got to dance with the girl that brung you, son. If you have a bit of business to do, do it quietly... in the corridors... in the subcommittees... with little amendments. You mess around on the big ones like Medicare, you'll be dead meat on election day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, then it's thanks for the memories, and on to the next gig.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know what your problem is, son? You don't think big enough. You have a real knack for this town, but you have the soul of a two-bit hustler. Listen to me, Tommy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            72.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five hundred thirty-five Members of Congress. Some are smart, and some stupid. Some good, some not. But all of them, son, all of them consumed by the single overriding imperative that defines the very Washington way of life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Getting re-elected.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. You're talkin' 'bout my re-election?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know what percent of the incumbents who ran last time got re-elected, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifty?   Sixty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ninety-six. And ninety-eight before that. It's like that election after election. If you don't fuck up, you can be here, raking it in, for life. Life, Johnson. Tommy considers this.   Then a big smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can think of worse places to get life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew you had it in you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So how do I get the Silver Foxes off my ass?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, throw them a bone... why don't you co-sponsor a bill for mandatory universal health insurance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            73.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.   It'll never pass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A couple of Lobbyists await Tommy. Van Dyke mans the desk. In come ELLEN JUBA, 40s, and her 13-year-old daughter, MICKEY, whose pony tail sticks out from her Florida Marlins baseball cap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I help you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I'm Ellen Juba. This is my daughter, Mickey. We'd like to see our congressman. We live in the district.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a moment, please. (dials; into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could you come out? Thank you. (hanging up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be right with you. (to Mickey)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like your hat. Loretta comes out and extends a hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you do, I'm Miss Loretta, public liaison for the congressman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellen Juba. My daughter Mickey. We'd like to see him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y'all from the district? Up    here seein' the sights? How'd you    folks like some gallery passes? Go    on over and listen to the great   debates of our day? She reaches into Van Dyke's desk drawer to get some passe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't want to go to the gallery. We want to see Congressman Johnson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            74.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How 'bout a House key ring for each of you? Here -- see that? Isn't that something? Turns into a pen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't understand. We're not tourists. We're constitutents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (helpfully)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You aren't with some organization, are you, honey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a goddam citizen! Isn't that enough!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not leaving here till we see him! Loretta exchanges a look with the Lobbyists, who get the picture. She picks up the phone and speaks nonchalantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Armando? Could you come out front, please? Tommy enters, carrying an enormous tennis trophy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look what I won! Must be that new racket. Armando has come out to hear this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There a problem, congressman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congressman?   You? Armando tries to escort her out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get your hands off me! Mickey tries to block Armando.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let go of her, you creep!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Careful, she may be armed!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop it!     Get away from her! Armando, defending himself from Mickey, manages to knock her hat off. With the hat comes her (apparently false) pony tail. ON MICKEY.   She's bald.    Her skull bears the mark of s Everyone stops.    It's quiet. Mickey's eyes burn into Tommy's.        Then she picks up hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Ma.      It's okay.    Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait.     What happened to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not just me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommy and his staff listen to the Jubas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was lucky. They said they got it all. I'm going to be okay. But what about the others?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The others?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They call it a "cancer cluster." Oh, at first, none of us in the neighborhood wanted to believe it, but then we all saw it -- for me, it was when the two-year-old across the street developed a brain tumor, same as Mickey. We looked at everything -- the water, the air, dump sites, insects, you name it. But we didn't have to look that far. It was staring us in the face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            76.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Power lines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: High-voltage power lines. The wires cause magnetic fields -- and the magnetic fields cause cancer. Especially in children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never heard of that. Mickey pulls a stack of journals and xeroxes from her book bag and gives it to her mother, who in turn gives the materials to Tommy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The studies, the numbers -- it's all there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Tommy, skeptical)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not actually going to read those, are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (caught)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, they'll be read...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you come see for yourself? Tommy has no quick answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Children playing on swings and seesaws in a small public park. TILT UP. A pair of electric power derricks carrying 225,000-volt lines almost directly overhead. The derricks cast shadows across a nearby school. We SEE the neighborhood. Quite a few FOR SALE signs. A house with a moving sale in progress on the front lawn. ON Tommy taking it all in.   With him are Celia and the Jubas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five children   in the neighborhood have cancer.    One more has precancerous   lesions. Pregnant women around   here are scared to death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            77.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Mickey's school?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turns out a lot of schools are near power lines. The land's cheap, so the schools tend to buy it from the power companies in the first place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But isn't the school district responsible?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We asked the superintendent to measure the magnetic field inside the school. He said, Okay, only it'll cost forty thousand dollars, and what program did we want him to cut that from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're nobody, congressman. You're somebody. We need your help. Tommy takes Celia aside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you believe it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's impossible to know. No one's really looked into it hard enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But why isn't it being investigated?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't they investigate breast implants all those years? What about those side-effects of that sleeping pill, Halcion? Why isn't anything being investigated? It's always the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Money talks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             78.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There must be something I can do for those people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't tell me you're actually developing a conscience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit, I hope not -- it'd be a fucking nuisance in Congress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, that's not fair. Some people on the Hill actually believe in things, and try to do a decent job, and don't forget why they went to Washington, and who sent them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (amazed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No shit. (remembering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah, I met one of those geeks. So what can I do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make a stink. Round up some Members and hold a press conference. Get that committee of yours to hold hearings. Haul in in the Environmental Protection Agency, the Surgeon General, the National Academy of Sciences. Get the issue on every breakfast table in America.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A press conference. Half a dozen congressmen, Tommy among them. Iowa is speaking to the few Cameras and Reporters. Beside him, Mickey Juba and her mother. Reinhardt and Ceila among the handful of staff and onlookers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This goes beyond personal tragedy. It goes to a public health hazard of unknown proportions. It goes to the right of ordinary people to know all the facts --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92              79

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, right -- people ought to know if their neighborhoods are killing them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amen, gentleman. Amen. They turn, somewhat surprised to see Dick Dodge, who joins Iowa at the microphones, a natural leader.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a fine effort this is. I am totally sympathetic. Congressional hearings should be scheduled as soon as possible. The American people deserve no less. He puts an arm around Mickey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Message:   we care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommy and Celia are watching the press conference on TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, congratulations. You've found yourself your own hopeless cause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Speaking of hopeless causes... They kiss, and slide OUT OF FRAME.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An impressive THUNDERSTORM pounds on Dodge's windows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pouring)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the rocks, or neat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever you're having.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            80.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, why ruin good bourbon with the taste of some shitty Sears icemaker, that's what I always say. (handing Tommy a glass)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheers. Dodge downs his drink.   Tommy follows suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Son, you're a real comer. I wouldn't be surprised if you ended up in the leadership. I'll say this: if I were Speaker, I'd sleep better with you as a lieutenant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, thank you, Mr. Chairman. You know, to tell you the truth, I didn't know you'd be on my side on those power lines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'm not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you said you were sympathetic --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course I did. We're all sympathetic to little girls with cancer. But I'm not sympathetic to holding an inquiry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you said --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what I said. But that was just a press conference, son. I wasn't under oath. The intercom BUZZES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?... Bring them right in! (hanging up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look. Son. It's great to get your name in the paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             81.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bet the gentleman from Iowa was all over the evening news in Des Moines tonight. Getting good press -- letting them know you care -- that's what it's all about. Smart move, Tommy. But that's as far as I'd go with this, if I were you. The door opens. Dodge turns to see Olaf Anderson, Tommy O'Connor, and Zeke Bridges enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a surprise!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Chairman!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Chairman! Hello, Tommy. Zeke you're looking well, good to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wheezing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good to see you, you old sum' bitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evening, Mr. Chairman, thanks for taking the -- Tommy, you s.o.b., they let you in here? (indicating Andersen and Bridges)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You folks finally get to press flesh! Olaf, meet Tommy Johnson. Tommy, Olaf Andersen. Chairman of Gulf Coast Power.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys here have told me a lot about you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah -- I told him you voted for him! They all share a laugh.    Except for Bridges, who squint at Tommy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glad to meet you, son. They tell me you've got a real talent for the game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            81A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this is Zeke Bridges, CEO of Pyramid Insurance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still puzzling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congressman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help me with these, would you, Tommy? He hands Tommy a couple of drinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Zeke)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chivas on the rocks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking the drink)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look awfully familiar. Tommy just smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommy and I were just talking about power lines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, what a coincidence. I thought this little party might be for me. (to Anderson)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You may not like this. (to Dodge)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we should hold those hearings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really fell for the line that parents group fed you, didn't you? Tommy is struck by Dodge's intelligence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd you know I met the parents group?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            81B.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I keep my ear to the ground, that's what a good politician does. Listen, Tommy, why don't we just get Olaf's take on this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's tragic, cancer's a terrible thing, but there's no way you can link it to power lines. Truth is, there's a bigger electromagnetic field given off by an electric blanket, or a microwave oven, than by those derricks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But there are studies that say --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For every study that says one thing, I'll show you a study saying another. We've studied it ourselves. Nada.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's not a single state health official anywhere in this country who says power lines cause cancer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what if you're wrong? As Tommy persists, Andersen looks increasingly angry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People didn't use to say smoking causes cancer, either. What if the evidence is just building, and some day we wake up and discover that your power lines are killing us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exploding)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Kill  us"? "Kill us"? You calling me a  murderer? You're saying there's blood  on these hands? How dare you talk  to me like that, you -- O'Connor puts a restraining arm on Andersen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Calm down, Olaf, calm down, he didn't mean it that way, did you, son? Alright, gentlemen. Easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             82.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Andersen backs off, regains his composure.    The outburs makes an impression on Tommy. Tommy

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just saying, it's worth looking into.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommy -- do you want to move the power lines? Do you know how much it would cost to bury them? Millions. Tens of millions. I don't have that money. The state doesn't have that money. You people up here sure don't have that money. You know who'd end up paying for it? Folks who sent you here, that's who.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now how'd you like the   people in your district to think   of you as the putz who tripled their   electric bill? You think they'd thank   you for that on election day?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I'm saying is, maybe we should hold hearings to look at --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think for a minute, boychik. You hold your hearings. Overnight, everyone who lives near a substation finds the value of his home in the toilet. You kill the real estate market.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You kill the insurance companies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You kill the school district.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You kill the local economy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a smart boy, you're not thinking very politically. Tommy watches the LIGHTNING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I should think about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             83.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, the system ain't perfect, but the fleas come with the dawg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, by the    way, Tommy, on a completely different    subject -- You don't have a state PAC    yet, do you? I'd like to give you a    hundred thousand dollar corporate    contribution to start one up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My company would be honored to do the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you do that?     I thought there were limits --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it's all aboveboard, we all believe deeply in the rules. It's just that the state rules are often more flexible about these things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you interested?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm always interested in the happiness of my constituents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll drink to that. Dodge and Andersen shoot each other a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommy pulls up in a Corvette with Florida congressional plates in front of his Capitol Hill row house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommy slips into bed next to Celia, who's half asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmmm...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            84.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmmm...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what did he say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dodge.    The hearings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh -- I, uh, haven't asked him yet. Celia suddenly looks quite awake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (casual)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't the right moment. Besides, I was thinking, maybe I ought to line up some other Members first -- you know, get my ducks in a row.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dick Dodge and several other towel-clad MEMBERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see that ABC poll?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Free fall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: President in trouble like that, he's liable to do something desperate. Some damn fool stunt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Invade Japan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Declare war on Congress, more like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 3/25/92             85

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The door opens.     Eli Marshall, fully dressed, comes in

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shafted me on the ethics bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            86.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Eli, good to see you.   Why don't you loosen your tie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a closed rule. I can't get my amendments on the floor. I can't get a recorded vote. I can't get squat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last time I looked, it was the Rules Committee in charge of that. This isn't the Rules Committee, Eli. This is the steam room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the U.S. Congress! The American people deserve better than --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what your problem is, Eli? You've got sermonitis. The other Members chuckle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't open your mouth without climbing into the pulpit, can you? Why don't you just calm down, have a massage --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got news for you, Dick. I'm going to run against you for Speaker. I may not have a rat's ass of a chance to beat you. But I sure as hell can tell the world the kind of sleaze you stand for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I went too far with him, I know it. You know him pretty well, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I don't know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, you play basketball together, you're seeing his niece, you've been to his church --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you know that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             87.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Dodge indicates his bloodhound nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll listen to you, Tommy. I want you to go make peace between us. Tell him we'll work something out on his amendments -- not a vote, I won't go that far, but at least he'll get to say his piece on the floor. Just get him off my back. Can you do that for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not a question, is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.     Is there a problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no -- I've still got my right nut, I can work with that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A WAITER removes an empty pitcher of beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, why not. Marshall takes a boiled crab from the platter between the places it on the butcher paper in front of him, christens it --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The honorable Dick Dodge. -- raises a big wooden mallet, and SMASHES it on the crab smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, Eli, sometimes people do things they regret. Everyone makes mistakes. Fact is, Dick's been under a lot of pressure lately --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That man's a walking quid quo pro -- prid quo -- quid pro quo, and you know it. He put you up to this, didn't he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             88.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't shit me, Tommy. You're Dick Dodge's yes-man. I know what you're up to. This is damage control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not a yes-man. When Dick says no, I say no. Marshall SMASHES down again with the mallet.    Crab carn

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know why no one on the Hill drops a dime on anyone else? Mutual assured destruction. Our little gentleman's agreement. Everybody has something on somebody, so nobody has anything on anybody, because everybody wants to save his own ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interested)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah? What do they have on you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They think I'm a pompous ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit, that ain't no secret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reinhardt and Loretta about to go in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure they don't want to be alone, Reinhardt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no -- I bet they've been talking about the ethics bill all night. Come on, Loretta, you'll know how to get Marshall's mind off business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit, this place isn't about passing laws any more. It isn't about doing good any more. All it's about is... being here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             88A

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Loretta and Reinhardt approach their table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, as I live and breathe.   Tommy! Tommy is surprised to see them.   She flashes a smile at Marshall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli, this is Loretta Hicks, from my staff. Loretta, Congressman Marshall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pleasure to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Entirely mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know Reinhardt, my AA? Marshall nods.   Reinhardt turns to Tommy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, congressman, could I just do a couple of quick calendar things with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Loretta)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you care for a drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell you the truth, nothing for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, when a pretty lady shoots him down, an old man knows it's time to go home. Marshall rises, pulling out his car keys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You kids have a good time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating pitcher)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, you gentlemen look like you've had a few -- Loretta, why don't you be a designated driver? Loretta stands and takes Marshall's keys from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             89.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excellent idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah.    The good Samaritan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, y'all. They leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now we've already got the Bankruptcy Institute breakfast tomorrow, but if you don't mind we could wedge in the Prune Board -- This isn't what Tommy wants to be doing now.    He gets u

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm packing it in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (also rising)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we talk while I drive you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, I'll walk. I could use the air.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Marshall and Loretta are singing. MARSHALL and LORETTA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Amazing grace, how sweet the sound, that saved a wretch like me -- "

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommy is on foot. Marshall's car, with its Maryland congressional plates, pulls over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, honey, no use you getting mugged.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: MARSHALL and LORETTA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I once was lost, but now am found; was blind, but now I see... " Tommy, in the back, cradles his head.   As Loretta heads into a traffic circle, she SEES THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             90.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: in high sling-back heels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning to look)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Check out the fuck-me pumps on that. Mm-mm. I gotta get me some shoes like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta!   Please! Your mouth!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a SCREECH of brakes and a CRUNCH of metal, a TAXI rear-ends them, SLAMMING Marshall's car into a lamppost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Taxi Driver looks at the wreck for a moment.   Then he lays rubber and SQUEALS away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the back floor, Tommy stirs. Seems to be okay. Lifts himself to see up front. The windshield is smashed. Loretta and Marshall are both unconscious. Tommy climbs into the front but can't get the door open. He kicks out a broken window and climbs through. He runs to a phone on the corner and dials 911.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need an ambulance right away. IN THE CAR no motion from Loretta or Marshall. AT THE PHONE he dials another number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evening, Mrs. Dodge, Tommy Johnson here, sorry to call at this hour, is Dick back from the Gridiron dinner yet? Could I speak with him for just a moment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS. DODGE is in bed. She hands the phone to Dodge, who's in white tie and tails, looking more sinister than splendid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommy Johnson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92           91.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong? INTERCUT Tommy and Dodge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good news doesn't come at this hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I went out with Marshall. We got into an accident. He's out cold. I'm okay. Dodge looks off balance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were you driving?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.   Someone else. Loretta. Dodge recovers his equilibrium.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girl from your office?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. She's out, too. I don't like the way it looks. For anybody. Look. You said you wanted to get back into Marshall's good graces. Well, here's an opportunity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen carefully. Tell the ambulance to take you to Walter Reed. It's a privilege they give congressmen. It's also the only hospital without a bunch of goddam reporters shtupping the nurses in exchange for leaks. They'll keep it quiet. I'll handle the police. You go home and keep your mouth shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two figures approach one another in the shadows: Reinhardt, and the Taxi Driver who rear-ended Marshall's car. The cabbie nods.   Reinhardt hands him an envelope. The Driver inspects the cash. THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             91A

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommy is shaving.   He HEARS the local tv news from the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and the Beltway is bumper-to bumper, so you might as well take a day of annual leave and enjoy yourself. At the top of the news, Maryland Congressman Elijah Marshall is in satisfactory condition at Walter Reed Hospital after an overnight accident in the District. Tommy bolts into the bedroom.    On the television he see

dialogues.speaker: VIDEO
dialogues.text: A CORRESPONDENT doing a stand-up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, Tom. Marshall reportedly had alcohol in his blood. Also slightly injured was an unidentified woman whom police say has a record in several states for prostitution. Tommy looks sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh sweet Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Linda, Congressman Marshall -- that's Reverend Marshall, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right you are, Tom. How this plays into his longstanding campaign to reform congressinoal ethics is now anyone's guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.   In other news... Tommy leaps for his clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommy races down the corridor.   Ahead of him, Celia, coming out of Marshall's room.   She freezes at the sight of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92              92

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get away from him. He approaches her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And get away from me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go away!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was set up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were set up? You were in the car! I didn't hear your name on the news!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, someone screwed him --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Someone"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Celia, something stinks here --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah -- it's you! You don't give a damn about anything! And to think, the other night, I actually thought you cared about someone else. He puts his hand to her face.    She brushes it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not me, you jerk -- Mickey Juba! You caved on those power lines, didn't you? I knew it. Damn it, I knew it! What did you get for it? Tommy O'Connor's box at the Redskins? Someone slip you a condo in the Virgin Islands?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you'd give me a chance to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92               9

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, I hate this town -- the only reason I stay is because I hate it so much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Celia --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get the hell out of here.

dialogues.speaker: MICKEY JUBA
dialogues.text: sitting on the ground, backs to us, beneath the power lines. A quiet moment. REVERSE ANGLE - TWO SHOT.   Mickey is shuffling a deck of cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it thumb over, or thumb under?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under. She tries her hand at a false shuffle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not bad, kid.    You've got potential.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what's happening? I thought you were going to kick some ass on -- She indicates the derricks.      Tommy looks at her, come a decision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am. He takes the deck from her, fans it face up, pulls all th kings and aces, stacks them on top, and squares the deck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
