dialogues.text: This is one's called the double duke. How many players?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's the mark?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            94.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She points to an imaginary poker player.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Number two -- over there. Tommy, smiling, calculates something for a moment, then gives the deck four shuffles. He hands Mickey the cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your deal. She deals out six hands in a circle on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at the sucker's hand. She turns over the hand at number two.   It has the four kings. Mickey WHISTLES at the hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at your hand. She turns over her own hand. It has the four aces. Mickey looks at the power lines, at the hands, at TJ. Then, understanding:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what you're going to do? Tommy nods.   Her face opens into a big smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's kick some ass.    What do I do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something very important.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommy pow-wows with Loretta Van Dyke, and Armando.   Asid from a sling, Loretta looks okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are we meeting here, Tommy? There trouble at the office?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impersonating Dodge)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I keep my ear close to the ground." His ear my ass. He had an inside man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That little fuck Reinhardt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             95.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hot damn -- I knew my driving wasn't that bad. Speaking of which -- you think I should wear one of those whiplash things, Tommy? There some insurance angle I should be working here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got bigger fish to fry, darlin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do we do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The big con.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We gonna git that sucker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dick always said I should think big.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa! Aren't we gettin' out of our league, man? That Dodge is a pro!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't con a con, Congressman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit, that's right, Tommy -- these politicians are serious slick fish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You people gone soft on me? Bunch of fuckin' incumbents I got here. Now listen up. Thursday morning Dodge has a breakfast with the Arts Caucus in the Longworth Room. Armando -- find out how fast I can get from Longworth to my office. Loretta -- we need some scoop from the EPA for the roper, I'll give you a list. Van Dyke -- call Hattie at the Silver Foxes, and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute -- we need a new roper, don't we? Everyone around here knows our faces. Outside a HORN sounds (O.S.).    Tommy looks at his watch

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            96.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right on the nose. He throws open the bay window of the narrow house. Just below is a pickup truck with "Homer's Pit Stop" lettered on the side. Homer gets out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My man! The others come to the window to see Homer, still wearing his fuel-smeared overalls, and SHOUT greetings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now let's get to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Members are being seated for a hearing. At the dais, Tommy approaches Dodge. A beat as Dodge studies Tommy's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli Marshall caught his tail in a crack, didn't he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You kept my name out of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I owe you one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleased)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You learn fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do me one favor, Dick. Next time you pull some heavy shit involving my ass, tip me off, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indulgent chuckle)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, son. (BANGS gavel)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This hearing of the Power and Enterprise Committee is now in order. The health of America's securities industry --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92              97

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Reinhardt approaches Tommy and slips him a packet of materials.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. Listen, Reinhardt, something's come up, and I don't quite know how to handle it. There's a guy from the EPA -- I don't know him -- says he wants to see me. Tonight. Out of the office. Alone, he says. Sound of it makes me nervous. I'd feel better if you were there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got it, jefe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man waits, alone, in the shadow of a large statue. It's Homer. In a jacket and tie, his stubble shaved off, he looks like a plausible government worker. Tommy and Reinhardt approach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Yancey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cold)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you'd be alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's my AA. He goes where I go. If you can trust me, you can trust him. Homer eyes Reinhardt a moment, then continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congressman, I have information I think you may want. It's about something going on at the EPA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What have you got?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got a wife and three kids, and a note on my house, that's what I got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            98.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothin' comes for nothin' in this town, do it? (to Reinhardt)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got any cash on you? I'm kind of light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't do that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Homer)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This stuff's pretty good?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the right hands, it could mean a great deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Sunday. Fifth race at Del Mar. Blueboy is running twenty to one. I'd take a major position.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to be shitting me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, not at all -- my Cousin Henry spends his days pumping water into horses' stomachs and stuffing Percodan up their butts. Trust me. Reinhardt is interested in this.   And he admires Tommy's m.o.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a moment)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright. The White House is putting heat on the EPA. They want us to announce a major investigation of the relation between power lines and cancer clusters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But didn't the EPA already do a study?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but when the draft got to the White House, they didn't like it. So they brought their own scientists in to kill it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            99.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did the White House change its mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who knows?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there new evidence?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah -- their polls have dropped like a rock. They need an issue. This one makes them look good on the environment, and they don't have to spend a penny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what good is this to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, congressman, in this town, information is currency. And advance information is gold. Reinhardt nods in agreement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you've    got to move fast. Once the White    House goes public with this, they    can't turn back. If your friends at    the power company want to kill this    investigation, they'd better do it now.     Evening, gentlemen. After Homer leaves:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blueboy. Twenty to one. Is your Cousin Henry always right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't got no Cousin Henry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reinhardt dials.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             100

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Dodge, it's Arthur Reinhardt. May I speak to the Chairman, please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sitting down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Longworth Room, a small circular committee room with an ornate rotunda. The Arts Caucus breakfast is ending.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unless there is further business, our caucus stands adjourned. Dodge gets up.    As he makes to leave, Tommy comes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got a minute, Dick? Tommy takes him aside.    The room empties except for the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Dick, I heard something. There's got to be some bid'ness in it. Tommy very discreetly gestures with his thumb and palm: money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe we can go in on it together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The EPA is going to make a stink about power lines. The White House is pushing them to do a big study.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's very interesting, my friend. I've heard that, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (acting surprised)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing gets by, do it? Tommy touches his nose, in tribute to the master.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            100A

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But thank you, son -- I'm glad you chose to share it with me. We do make quite a team, don't we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I -- I hope it wasn't my press conference that started this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, this is a stunt for the polls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So do you think there's something in it for us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (musing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we got the EPA off Olaf Andersen's back, he'd be extremely appreciative.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how do we do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My committee writes the EPA's programs. We audit their funds. We confirm their appointees. I've got them by the balls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you're going to -- ? Tommy makes a squeezing gesture, grins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no, not at all -- just... persuasion. Strenuous persuasion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's allowed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Persuasion, yes. Intimidation, no. But it's a gray area. Who's to say which is which?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dick, wait a minute -- shouldn't we check out the tip? Make sure the EPA's really going through with this investigation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             101

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. (looks at watch)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He should be in by now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skeeter Warburton, of course. Always go right to the top, son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dodge passes his Secretary's desk on the way into his office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get me the EPA Administrator, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommy jogs along the corridor. A tourist Family stares at him. He explains his haste with a smile --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a vote on the floor. -- and ducks into the stairwell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a chamber crammed with cables, the Telephone Man listens to a handset. He now sports a gold Rolex on his wrist -- his horse must have come in. Van Dyke, also there, looks at any array of dials and meters, whose hands all suddenly move. Some electronic phone CHIRPS, then the filtered RINGING of a call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here he comes. The Telephone Man nods, adjusts some wiring, smiles satisfiedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And there he goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta wears a beaded sling, which adds to her look. She is at Tommy's desk, watching his phone as it RINGS. Tommy comes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             102

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Administrator. Loretta picks up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Office of the Adminstrator. (listens)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, I'll put you right through. She hands the phone to Tommy, who mimics the George Plimpton voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Warbuton here. (listens)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. (waits)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Chairman! I do hope there's something I can help you with today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need a straight answer from you, Skeeter. Is the White House on your ass about power lines?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Off the record?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was looking forward to some serious sailing this week -- Tish and I have a lovely spot right by Kennebunkport. Instead, here I am at three in the morning, writing testimony to your committee about cancer clusters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for your candor, Warburton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at all. You must come sailing with us. Cheers. Bye-bye. Tommy passes the phone back to Loretta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next. THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            102A

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zeke Bridges on line two. Andersen punches the button to connect the call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll just put you through to him. She passes the phone to Tommy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Olaf? (coughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Olaf, Zeke Bridges. Listen, you sum' bitch, I'm so mad, I can't sit down to shit. Have you heard what I heard? (wheezes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INTERCUT with Andersen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The EPA's fixing to make a big stink about power lines and cancer. They're going to serve us up for breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. There's no scientific proof --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Proof don't mean shit. We're talking politics. They make a federal case out of power lines, I'm screwed. Whole insurance business is screwed. You know how much cash I'd have to pay out in settlements? Even if I stiffed everybody on claims, the legal fees'd be enough to kill me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             103

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You better believe it. You're screwed, too. Every hot dog trial lawyer in America soon be lining up to sue both our asses. We got to move on this, Olaf. If I wasn't tied up here, I'd go to Washington myself. Shouldn't you be getting on a plane? Just between us -- you find a way to stop this, I'll find a million bucks if I have to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A very worried Andersen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommy and Dodge walking along a Capitol hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Olaf will be at my office at five o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do we play it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cool. Real cool. You just follow my lead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know how I can help you on this one, Olaf. This is the EPA. This is the President.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is my lifeblood!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see that, Olaf, I see that. But in this town, you pick your fights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This could mean six figures, Dick. Dodge says nothing, but makes his eyebrows fly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: High six figures. Dodge flicks his eyebrows again:   More.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             104

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seven figures?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Between us. It's not that much -- what can you get for half a million these days?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How the hell can I funnel that kind of money to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If that's what you want, we can always find a loophole. No one will see your fingerprints.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one will know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one will know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're only in trouble if someone can prove a connection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course there's no connection. Olaf's just making a contribution as a patriotic citizen. And in return for it, he's getting --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good government.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly.   A little access, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dodge, Andersen, Tommy, and O'Connor walking along. Up ahead, a cocktail reception. On an easel by the door:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got to do a drop-by. You gentlemen like to join me for a drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dodge and Tommy work the room genially. Tommy spots Celia talking to some Guests and goes over to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            105.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Guests, smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me. She turns, starts to walk away.   Tommy stops her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look. Whatever you think of me, just promise me one thing. She glares at him angrily.   But then she's surprised to hear:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come to the Clean Air hearing tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (baffled)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Power and Enterprise.    Noon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But why? He gives her an enigmatic smile and slips away. As he rejoins Dodge, Tommy SEES WARBURTON enter the room. Alarmed, TOmmy moves in on Dodge, steering him to avoid the EPA Administrator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shouldn't we be heading off, Dick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's work the room just a bit more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congressman!   Mr. Chairman! As Dodge turns to see him --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evening, Reinhardt. -- he SEES Warburton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            106.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good to see you, sir.    By the way, I thought your opening   statement in committee yesterday was   brilliant. Dodge points out Warburton to Tommy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well. Look who's over there -- Skeeter Warburton from the EPA. The very man we want to see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to turn him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you tried the oysters, Dick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At a hazardous waste event? (shakes head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we'll go talk to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he's the wrong man --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bemused by Tommy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't understand -- he's the perfect man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But -- but you don't want to bother him with this. Talk to one of his underlings -- Dodge looks at Tommy with curiosity, not understanding hi reluctance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing beats man-to-man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here?     Not here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A public place. What could be better?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it's the wrong time!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While the iron is hot, son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92               1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chiming in helpfully)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No time like the present.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up, Reinhardt, I'm talking to the Chairman. Beat it, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling to Dodge)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll go get him. Reinhardt heads for Warburton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puts hand on abdomen)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You heard about this stomach thing going around?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, son, we've got the people's business to do. He leads Tommy off to one side.      Reinhardt brings Warburton to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Chairman.    Congressman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got a big problem, Skeeter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your power lines investigation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What power lines investigation? Tommy is sweating bullets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're off the record, Skeeter. This witch-hunt for cancer clusters is bad news for everyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what you're talking about, Dick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             108

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, I know you're being a good soldier --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm being straight with you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then let me be straight with you. You announce this study -- I'm not talking about the results down the road, mind you, I'm just talking about the announcement -- and there's broken crockery everywhere. Real estate. Utilities. Insurance. Schools. Local governments. It'll cost jobs. Uproot families.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I agree with you completely. There isn't going to be an investigation, old chap, I promise you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad we understand each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I think we do. Tommy silently rejoices in his good fortune.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we'll just forget about that phone call this morning?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We didn't speak on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (vastly impressed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excellent. Dodge claps him on the shoulder, then heads off with Tomm who is delighted to have dodged a bullet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (imitating Warburton)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "There isn't going to be an investigation, old chap."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chuckling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92           109.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They join up with Andersen and O'Connor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto voce)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Worked like a charm. We scared him shitless. The investigation's dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waiter! Champagne! (to Dodge)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you at the Clear Air hearings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Reinhardt comes into the office, Tommy intercepts him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning, Reinhardt! Got a minute? I need your advice on something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Tommy leads him back into the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Van Dyke, Armando, and Loretta work the phones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this the assignment desk? Yes, I'm calling from Chairman Dodge's office, on the Hill. We wanted to be sure CNN was sending a crew to the Clean Air hearing today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, not the new emission standards. We're breaking news. This is the biggest thing since Watergate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Cynthia Leeson in the White House Press Office. My boss wanted me to let you folks know -- we're making a major announcement at the Clean Air hearings today. (listens)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I can't tell you, but it's hot. (listens)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if the New York Times wants to be the only paper in town to miss the story of the year, that's up to y'all. THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92              10

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommy has drawn Reinhardt into the cage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to do a little    something nice for Dodge. That     EPA thing -- he's been good to me,    Reinhardt. Is there some way I can,    like, throw a bouquet to him at the    hearing today without having to sit    through that boring testimony    shit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you ask him to give you the floor at the start?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For some flattery? In a New York minute. Just tip him ahead of time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good thinking. They return to the corridor.     Tommy looks at his watch

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, Reinhardt, my Grandma's plane comes in at ten. You wouldn't mind picking her up and driving Miss Daisy around, would you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't one of the others do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I don't trust them the way I trust you. TOMMY pats him on the back and sends him on his way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommy, joined by his cronies and the Jubas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is it, people.     Game time.   Let's get it right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me one thing, jefe. How do you know Andersen is going to bite?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't.   You run a con, you run a risk. THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             110

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hundred or so members of the public -- trade groups, Hill staffers, lawyers, tourists -- settle into their seats. VAN DYKE escorts Hattie Rifkin and a busload of Silver Foxes. Loretta comes in with Ellen and Mickey Juba. GRANDMA comes in, on Reinhardt's arm. She is dressed up as a biddy, down to a hat with fruit on it. COMMITTEE MEMBERS head for their seats at the dais. OLAF ANDERSEN is at the witness table, along with a coupl of other businessmen. In a seat behind Andersen, Tommy O'Connor. THE PRESS.   A good turnout, with several camera crews.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what this is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (confidential)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's very hot. Electric cars. CELIA is seated with Ira, her Pro Bono associate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm cutting out early.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating TJ)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't want to run into him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got that right. AT THE DAIS Tommy has a private word with Dodge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dick, I thought it might be a nice way to open if I congratulated you on the fine work you been doin' on this committee. Really express our appreciation. Especially on behalf of the minority community.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, thank you, son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            111.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating cameras)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wouldn't hurt to have tape like that in the bank, would it, Mr. Speaker? HOMER slips in next to Reinhardt, who is surprised to see him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Yancey? Arthur Reinhardt.      Are you testifying for the agency?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leaning over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Homer, dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Mrs. Johnson, you must be mistaken -- let me introduce you. This is Mr. Yancey of the EPA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Reinhardt)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be silly, child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer Norton. Homer's Pit Stop, Axahatchee, Florida.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer's known Tommy since they were in diapers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the -- ? From the row behind Reinhardt, Armando clamps Reinhardt down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Move and you're history. DODGE GAVELS the meeting to order.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This meeting of the Power and Enterprise Committee to consider the reauthorization of the Clean Air Act is now in session. Today's first business is a panel of national leaders in the field of utilities.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            112.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before I welcome them, Chair would like to yield to the gentleman from Florida for a word. If there is no objection from the Committee -- ? The gentleman may proceed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Chairman, on behalf of the other members of this committee, and on behalf of myself, I have a very personal statement to make. From the bottom of my heart, I want to thank you -- thank you for your leadership, for your insight, for your boldness... Dodge preens for the cameras, until:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and for your courage. Especially your courage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My courage?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your courage in exposing the corruption that eats away at this institution. Your courage in taking on the special interests. Your courage in taking a major new step --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I've... I've... I've done nothing new, nothing at all -- what are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're    right -- integrity isn't new to you,    Mr. Chairman, it's second nature    to you. Still it's a rare public    servant who'll take on the special    interest money, take on the PACs -- ANDERSEN, wary, senses danger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: take on the lobbyists and fat cats -- CELIA is fascinated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            113.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and who'll stand up instead for ordinary American citizens...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... the plain people who just want peace of mind -- who just want to know they're raising their kids in safe neighborhoods and sending them to safe schools. ON THE DAIS Dodge wants to wrap this up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, courage, Mr. Chairman, is a quality that you have in abundance --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, yes, thank you, but we have to move along, if the gentleman would --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (undeterred)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen, yesterday, the Chairman and I had a meeting in his office with Olaf Andersen of Gulf Coast Power, and his lobbyist, Mr. Tommy O'Connor -- (indicating)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: these gentlemen here. Chairman Dodge and I listened in astonishment as Olaf Andersen offered us seven figures -- that's one million dollars, ladies and gentlemen. A BUZZ in the room.   O'CONNOR leans forward to Andersen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dodge double-crossed us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're fired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One million dollars, if we would stop the EPA from investigating the connection between power lines and cancer clusters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            114.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Shocked MURMURS sweep the room. REINHARDT is aghast. HOMER and ARMANDO are delighted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't that right, Mr. Andersen? Tommy flicks his eyebrows at Andersen, provocatively, imitating Dodge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a vicious lie. Dodge GAVELS sharply, turns to Tommy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will the gentleman yield?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not possible! You can't give anyone that kind of money! Dodge continues GAVELING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, you can. As Mr. O'Connor said to you, quote: "If that's what you want, we can always find a loophole. No one will know." Remember saying that, Tommy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do not!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (standing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I insist that the gentlemen yield! Tommy also stands, and produces a video tape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't deny it, Mr. Andersen! We have the whole thing on this tape! The room erupts. THE PRESS loves it. Still cameras CLICK and WHIR. DODGE despairs. REINHARDT puts his hand over his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yesterday, at Chairman Dodge's courageous suggestion, I taped the whole conversation. It's all there. Mr. Chairman, I thank you. The people thank you. America thanks you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92               1

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: AUDIENCE APPLAUDS DODGE. The clapping is considerably sweetened by the Panthers and the rest of Tommy's claque. DODGE gauges their reaction, gets an inspiration. The storm leaves his face, and becomes a smile, which he beams on Tommy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thank the distinguished gentleman. And I thank my fellow citizens. Our methods in this investigation may have been unorthodox, but together -- (indignant, at Andersen)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: we have exposed a canker at the very heart of democracy. APPLAUSE. Tommy is amazed at Dodge's survival skills. REINHARDT, delighted at the turn, claps heartily. ANDERSEN, livid, leaps up and shouts at Dodge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bastard!    You set me up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Witness is out of order!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You stood to make a million bucks off of me! Who offered you more? I want to know! A new BUZZ sweeps the room. O'Connor tries to restrain Andersen, who sloughs him off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're as big a whore as he is! MICKEY JUBA catches Tommy's eye and mouths a question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now? Tommy shakes his head:   no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The phone by Eli Marshall's bed RINGS.    He answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?  No. You're joking. (to Man in next bed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mind if I put on C-span? THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            116.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no loyalty any more, is there, Dick? What about the three hundred grand you squeezed from me for that goddam voter registration front of yours -- that just water under the bridge? O'Connor tries again to restrain him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't touch me, you scum! MICKEY JUBA mouths:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now? Tommy shakes his head again.    No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the two hundred k for your phony foundation, Dick? How about the ten thousand copies if your goddam autobiography you muscled me to buy -- what's all that, ancient history? Andersen advances toward the dais, pointing now to six or seven other Members of the Committee among the total of 28.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you -- what about those bundled checks from my executives? I gave you my condo in Vail! I gave you my corporate jet to fly all over the world! I gave your kids summer jobs! I put up scholarships to put your kids through college! I hired your goddam wife to redecorate my office! You telling me none of that counts for anything? Andersen grabs Dodge by the throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you people were for sale! I was wrong -- you're just for rent! Dodge struggles free of Andersen, who is dragged away fro Dodge by Capitol Police.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92              11

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How dare you impugn my integrity! Everything I've done has been completely legal!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (acting astonished)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Chairman! You mean to say you did all that stuff? You took all that money? Shock in the room. Some BOOS. IOWA does a nice HOG CALL. TJ sends a little wave and smile to Celia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nothing I've done that -- (indicating other Members)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- that these gentlemen haven't done! Committee Members rush to dissociate themselves from Dodge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!... Not me!... Just him!... I never!... He crossed the line!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're whores! All of them! MICKEY JUBA tries again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now? TJ nods yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Throw the bums out! LAUGHTER and APPLAUSE.   She's touched a nerve.   TJ leap into the moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn straight! Throw the bums out! This place is an outhouse! ON THE PUBLIC. GASPS, WHOOPS, and APPLAUSE.    Reinhardt sinks lower and lower into his seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Throw the bums out! Throw the bums out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            118.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Tommy, enjoying the triumph, can't help rubbing Dodge's n in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I owed you one. Dodge wheels on Tommy, exploding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You lowlife hustler! Who are you to talk? You got into this House through fraud. You think I didn't check up on you? He pulls a piece of paper from the pile at his place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ladies and   gentlemen, I have here some rather   startling revelations about this   Mr. Johnson before you. This man is   nothing but a con man! A fresh BUZZ from the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A common grifter! (consulting paper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's wanted in three counties for bunco! He's a convicted swindler! Some BOOS.   REINHARDT emerges from his hole, encouraged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fugitive from justice for card sharping, bookmaking, confidence games --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and other charges the FBI has only begun to investigate! I dare you to respond! A hush in the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what? He's right!     But let me tell you something --   all that's nothing, compared to   what I pulled here in Washington...   and this shit's all legit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            119.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: LAUGHTER and APPLAUSE.   Dodge BANGS the gavel repeatedly

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gentleman is out of order! The gentleman is out of order! This committee is adjourned! GRANDMA leaps to her feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop banging! Stop banging!      That man has something to say! Massive APPLAUSE. Dodge is stunned by the enormity of the sentiment against him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adjourned? Fine. Leave. (indicating cameras)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turn your backs on the whole country. That what you want to do, gentlemen? The Members remain in place, paralyzed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the room)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a con man. A small-time con man. Do you know what it was like for me to come to Congress? It was for like dying and going to heaven. If I did back home the kind of scams I've run in Congress, my ass would be in Sing Sing. But no, I'm not a crook -- up here, I'm a distinguished gentleman!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli, watching on television.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now don't get me wrong. They're not all bums. But boy, do the rotten fish stink up the barrel. Marshall APPLAUDS.   The Man in the next bed joins in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now tell me, people -- while these guys are buying and selling each other, who's standing up for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            120.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you who. Nobody! Nobody gets five hundred bucks an hour to lobby for the average Joe! There's no Shnook PAC! There's no National Association for Ordinary Assholes! Sure, everyone's against cancer, but "everyone" doesn't have an office on K Street! (to committee Members)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you folks get it? We're supposed to be the people's lobbyists. Congress is supposed to be America's political action committee. APPLAUSE and SHOUTS of support. Several Members on the dais join the applause, seeing a winning issue. CELIA shakes her head in wonder. Tommy goes to Mickey and stands her up on a chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's right. Throw the bums out -- starting with me! I'm gonna found me a new party. The Don't Vote For Me Party. Any of y'all want to join up? APPLAUSE and CALLS of enthusiasm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, come on, then! C'mon, get up, we got work to do! The room erupts, electrified, chanting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Throw the bums out! Throw the bums out! Tommy is engulfed by people and lights. Dodge, Andersen, and O'Connor -- desperate, snarling -- are pinned to the wall by the SHOUTING Press Corps. Loretta AND GRANDMA watch Tommy bask in his new notoriety.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That Miss Oprah's gonna love his ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92               1

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: CELIA arrives where Tommy is standing.   She looks at him a beat. Then a big smile. They kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommy Johnson. Kamikaze congressman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommy and Celia walk down the steps, arm in arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't wait to see that tape you made. Tommy pulls it from his pocket, glances at it, and tosses it away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? I bought it this morning. It's blank. As they continue down the steps, CAMERA CRANES UP to WIDE SHOT of the Capitol and the town beyond.
